description: Came in and was greeted by our waiter Ken. He was friendly, fast and efficient. We ordered the Tomato Beef Chow Mein, Sweet and Sour Chicken, Fish and veggies. We ordered the lunch portions and it tastes good. Pay by cash to avoid the credit card fed charge. Thanks again Ken.
author: Jaxxxie P.

description: The jai, or vegetarian food is great here. I'm a huge fan of tofu and it's everywhere on the menu haha. If you come here, you must order their fried green onion pancakes! They're the best I've had so far. Super crunchy and flavorful. Their service is pretty good. It's crazy how they can carry the big bowl of soup with only one arm! Speaking of soup, I found a fly in it, which goes to show how the restaurant isn't the cleanest.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Bought takeout during lunch time.  The guy who took my order was nice and cordial.  

You could pay with a credit card but there's an extra charge.  

Shrimp with Scrambled Eggs Over Rice $8.50 -  Taste is 3/5 but the portion amount was 1/5.
The rice was good and was chewy.  The eggs were tasty.  The amount was only half a container.  Not worth the $8.50.  

I will not return to this restaurant.
author: J W.

description:
There's lipstick on the tea cup from previous customer. Red lipstick on a white tea cup. How can the waiters miss this when they prepare the table?

CREDIT CARDS!!! They now charge you an addition 4% if you want to use a credit card. Luckily I had cash, because I've never been to any restaurant or store that charges you additional 4% just because I want to use a credit card.
author: Jack L.

description: Apparently every chinese restaurant I enjoy eating at has a bad health score. LOL 4 stars for their vegetarian dishes. I would go back for their regular menu when we don't have to eat vegetarian that day. Service is fast and friendly. I don't know what their kitchen looks like, but it seems to be a popular place.
author: Gessa C.

description: I love this place, but we just tried to go tonight and it has been closed by the health department. I hope they can reopen soon
author: Maxine L.

description: I went to pick up some dinner tonight and it's shut down. I will avoid this place in the future.
author: Michelle T.

description: Must try Chinese food. Dont let the outside fool you. The food is delicious and authentic. Interior could be cleaner but I love the old school vibe. Prices are great and portions are large. I recommend the Salty fish with tofu claypot.
author: Ernest M.

description:
Apparently if the male waiter recognizes you as a regular, he greets you warmly otherwise, he'll dump your table settings and menus without acknowledgement.

I don't care how "good" the food might be.... you're still getting one star for the sh#tty service.
author: Steven L.

description: Service is good, food is good can't complain, two thumbs up! Parking is tough but we're in the city afterall. If you come here i highly recommend their ox tail pot!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
What a pleasant surprise. For under $9 including tip, you get a big bowl of wonderful homestyle soup, and lots of expertly wokked chicken, green beans and mushrooms in a savory sauce with a giant bowl of rice.
A normal person would make two meals out of it. Heh heh
I like how the free tea is also loose leaf and not bags. 
They could turn on the heater, but bundle up and you'll be fine. Really tasty.
author: Lisa T.

description:
The place doesn't look welcoming but it's not bad, I was surprised to walk into the establishment and seeing no one at the front desk to give seats or take orders of the people that walk in. I went in to order take out, gave my order and was told to wait. The wait was about 30 to 35 minutes, I don't really mind the wait if I'm getting great food. 
However when I got my food, I realized that the beef flat noodles that I ordered weren't freshly made because noodles were all stuck to each other and the noodles were hard and stiff. Safe to say, I won't be ordering from there any time soon.
author: April X.

description: Great food .open for many years and always inexpensive and Good quality food.my favorite Chinese food fix.
author: Tony m.

description: Authentic hole in the wall Chinese place with huge portions and cheap prices. my favorite place for comfort food in the sunset area. Started comjng here with family a few years back and have been coming back myself ever since. Theyre known for their bomb ass vegetarian dishes because a lot of Buddhists customers dont eat meat (holla at my mom who only orders the vegeterian fried rices, dumplings, and imitation seafood/meat dishes). tho I prefer their general tso chicken, deep fried wings, oxtail soup, and mongolian beef :p sorry mom
author: Chesley C.

description: Me and my parents have been coming here for years and have always enjoyed it, friendly staff and authentic good Chinese food. Unfortountly this place has roaches :( a cockroach climbed up my moms left over oxtail stew and we looked up at the wall and seen another one!!!! (We were seated upstairs btw)...
author: Haley R.

description:
The food and service was so good.  Very pleasant surprise! Cozy space and simple layout.  We were at the SF zoo all day and needed to eat dinner.  This hit the spot!
We will definitely come back again for the food and service and affordable menu.  I recommend you try it!!
author: Laura Z.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday evening with my familiy. It was quite empty. 

The plates and everything were already set up. We asked for waters and unfortunately I found some old food stain inside of my glass... Gross.

I can't remember everything we ordered but it was one of the combo family dinners that they provide. We got the Hot and sour soup, Deep fried flounder, Mabo tofu. Shredded pork & bak choy - all decent but not really satisfying... I had to pour a lot of pepper into my hot and sour soup to make it taste decent =/. The friend flounder didn't come with much soy sauce at the bottom so it was quite dry from the skin... The mabo tofu was semi-salty but nothing rice can't help! The shredded pork and bak choy was decent. I would get that again if I came here.

The bill came out to be quite expensive for what we got.... 5 or 6 dishes (including the soup) was $60 or so, like wtheck. I can definitely get a better price else where.
author: Nicole C.

description: We come here every time we visit for the holidays. It's just one of those places where you can get decent inexpensive Chinese food. This is still our go-to place for black bean beef chow fun w/ gravy because no place makes it better. It has that yummy smoky wok flavor that I can still taste in my mouth. All of their other dishes are yummy. Unfortunately their menu prices went up about 20% from our last visit but we're still coming back time and time again.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Referred by a friend, I chose to order off the menu for a family dinner for four at home.  Like me, she is local, growing up in the City and familiar with all the old staple restaurants that the "Lo Wah Kue", long-time immigrants, would know and loved.  Having a similar palate, I trusted her recommendation of trying this sleepy spot in the Sunset right on the L streetcar line.  She painted a picture of their ox tail dish in my mind that made me bookmark this place on my 'to try' list.  On a recent Saturday evening, here's what I ordered:

1) West Lake beef soup - Hard to do wrong and all elements were there especially not being too thick.  Parents were too hungry to wait for my camera to click this one.

2) Ox tail in wine sauce (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Main reason for coming here.  Loved that they use the smaller pieces which are more tender.  The wine sauce with onions and carrot chunks are great with rice.

3) Pei Pa Tofu (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ihu84OYnESDwsPUyulq8QA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Seeing photos from other reviews, I ordered this.  Tasty deep fried tofu balls mixed with ham pieces.  The broccoli was perfectly cooked, still crunchy yet cooked.  Like the ox tail, the gravy/sauce on this pairs well with rice.

4) Surf clam (3) stir fry with bean sprouts, chives, and ginger (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3p1poDDbf7X6cu5PJ84AAg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Ordered this by mistake, wanting the traditional steamed open shell version with vermicelli, this was just okay.  The clam flavors were dominated by the ginger and bean sprouts. Will make sure to order correctly the next time.

5) Fook-chow style fried rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8FNzmS4DZQsvQQZpA6sxHg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Decent version of this 'wet' fried rice though more of a poor man's version with the main ingredients being shrimp, chicken, shiitake mushrooms, and Chinese broccoli slices (gai lan).  The true version usually includes dried and/or bay scallops which were MIA here.  Again, the sauce was nicely done.

If you grew up on the '60's and '70's in San Francisco's Chinatown community, you'll remember that rice and gravy was extremely popular, meeting two big requirements:  a) filling and b) flavorful.  The cooking style here fits that profile based on the dishes that our family tried.  The dining room is average in size with about four large banquet size tables and six or seven four-seat tables.  At around 5 pm on a Saturday, there were four or five occupied tables already.  The cashier was kind and efficient in accepting my payment and packing my meal.  Based on these dishes, I would rate the food 3.5 stars, adding 0.5 star for satisfying my family's tastes.
author: Mike C.

description:
I never knew this place existed of all the years I lived in the Sunset. Based on the way it looks, I would have never walked in here, and my friends never mentioned this place, and for good reason. 

I was with my worker doing some light construction jobs nearby, and he brought me here for lunch. He ordered some beef stew with rice dish & I ordered Mongolian Beef w/ rice. My dish was sweet, and not a bit of spicy kick that I come to expect from all the years that I've had this elsewhere. There were no peppers at all. His beef stew dish appeared dull & gray. I tried a couple of bites and the beef was tough, bland & very chewy. They used the cheapest parts of the cow. (at least I hope it caem from a cow)

This restaurant strikes me as a place for Chinese contractors and mechanics to get a quick, cheap lunch. The guy who brought me here also knew some guys at another table that looked like they were taking a break from doing remodeling work. 

I'm not sure about the other menu items but our lunch experience was enough to help me decide I am not coming back. The service is what you might expect from a truly authentic Chinese dive, lacking, as was flavor of the food.
author: James L.

description: Don't be discouraged by the layout of the restaurant, the food is surprisingly good and very reasonably priced. I will be back for more!
author: Yvonne W.

description: Horrible service.  Without a doubt.  Long wait for takeout so I observed waitstaff too.  My expectations are low at Chinese restaurants as baseline so my annoyance is magnified here.  Ordered takeout. Told would be ready in 15 mins.  I waited 45 mins!  Complained a few times.  Waiter blew me off and said Chinese equivalent of "oh well" .  Owner wasn't helpful.
author: Rubyreg R.

description: Been here at least over 15 times here. The food is consistent, wait staff is responsive, good portions, tables are well spaced not jammed up together. For good old fashion Cantonese stir fried dishes if I'm in this neighborhood. Restaurants been here for over 20 years, so its not a fly by night staff. We always tend to over order on dishes b/c the portions are huge so come prepare to eat. It's getting harder in San Francisco to find affordable restaurants to take the whole family to in residential neighborhoods & within walking distance.
author: Stevie C.

description:
I order their salt and chile pepper tofu, mm so good and fried and tasty.

Their hot and sour soup left something to be desired; skip if you are a fan of that style soup.

This place is decent, don't overthink it.

It's not a gem, but it isn't a piece of **** either.
author: Auza A.

description: The food taste really good, excellent portions, the waiters are nice, and helpful. Finding a spot to park can be challenge.
author: Lawrence C.

description: The food is so traditional here! One of the best Cantonese restaurants in the Bay Area! We always hold our family celebration events here.
author: Jimmy W.

description: Food is great, I work right across the street so I always used to eat here. Until I saw 2 huge exterminator trucks outside the other night when I closed at my job. Never again, lol food tastes good though.
author: Jasmine C.

description: The food taste really good. The staff help me with the menu and they are super kind. The price is really good and the portion is Excellent!!!!! They have been open for 22 years, so they know how to treat costumer. They give me free egg puff on my first order and free pancake for second order. I love it!!!
author: Merry H.

description: Nice sized portions. Extensive menu with plenty of seafood. Prices very reasonable. Haven't had anything that I haven't liked. If you're in the area check it out. 2/2018 - No longer a cell phone dead area. Now charging 4% to pay with credit card. (Illegal in CA)
author: David G.

description:
Okay...so granted the night that we came also happened to be a night that SF decided to pour, so I guess I shouldn't be surprised that we were the only table for most of our meal. But because we were, I was disappointed that some of the dishes we ordered still came out incorrect - what's the excuse for that?

The rundown: the deep fried pork chops were delivered piping hot and as a platter full. Woot! The tofu and fish claypot was equally yummy. Fried tofu was plenty and the fish was pretty good as well. Our sliced rock cod and string beans came with bok choy instead, which was pretty disappointing. The rock cod was also less than stellar. Pieces just kind of fell apart. And our black pepper beef came with way more onions than beef which was pretty lame as well. But at least they provided soup to start and dessert to finish.

Their lotus root soup is very yummy. Just like how grandma makes it. As for dessert, last time we came, they had eggettes...but this time it was a more traditional green bean soup. Bleh.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Very decent Chinese food with both delicious vegetarian and meat options. Came here for my grandma's birthday dinner on a Saturday and it so happens another birthday dinner was going on with the entire floor booked.. so I guess while we had reservations around 7 we didn't get seated until 730-8pm. 

Food came out very fast. Love the sweet and sour spare ribs, duck, fried noodles with enoki, chicken and egg soup and especially the greens&enoki soaked in sauce. I wasn't a big fan of their fish or lobster. Sadly the fish was too fishy for me, and the lobster was too salty; tasted like they put too much oyster sauce for flavoring.

All in all, good restaurant with good service. The waiter we had was really funny and super attentive. Too bad we got stuck at the top where the air circulation wasn't so great and it got super stuffy especially with another party next to us. I wouldn't mind coming back for more yummy Chinese food. Really cool how they are known for vegetarians loving their stuff!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
We were on a mission to restock the freezer with bundles from the KIngdom of Dumpling shop, and thought we'd try their restaurant, because we'd never been there.  When we saw a line coming out the door, we knew this was not going to be the day.  We were too hungry.

So with so many Chinese restaurants on Taraval, and not having a particular fave, we let the proximity of parking (which is VERY tricky in these parts) determine which one we picked.  For something so random, Ming's turned out so much better than we expected.  My husband had the Szechuan chicken on the lunch and I got the vermicelli with duck and snow cabbage.  We both started off with the soup, which didn't look very inviting, but turned out tasting like cabbage borscht, in a good way.  Both portions were large, and although it hadn't been our original intent, we ended up sharing both.

Mine was a little bland, but the noodles were a perfect texture.  I am suspicious that it was not duck, though.  Tasted more like chicken, and I didn't see anything that looked like what I imagined snow cabbage would look like, but I enjoyed it especially with some Szechuan chicken and it's very flavorful sauce mixed in.  The chicken by itself was a little too strong, although I didn't object to any of the flavors, it was just too much sauce for the amount of chicken, so perfect on intensity when mixed with my vermicelli.  We spent a total of $15, including tax and tip; can't beat that! 

 I loved that we were the only non Chinese there.  There were lots of interesting items I'd like to go back and try.  It wasn't until after I left that I read Yelp and saw they specialize in vegetarian.  Also, there was a separate menu (all in Chinese) that was given out to most of the other tables (but not us).  I wonder what was on it?  I saw the Dragon Balls on some one else's table and wondered what they were.  I would definitely try those!, and after Ken K.'s description, I would definitely try the #147 clay pot.

It was really a 3.5 for me at this point, but I'll round up anticipating the good things I've yet to try.
author: Diane B.

description: Mings is a solid place to go for honest old school Chinese food. This place has been around for 20 plus years and is family owned and operated. I like this spot for there amazing soups and my favorite dish there is the sizzling chicken with fermented black bean sauce. It's amazingly affordable and delicious, everyone there is friendly and service is super fast. Check it out and skip the dim sum lines
author: dan m.

description: Always do take out. My staples are beef chow fun, shredded pork and bean sprouts pan fried noodles, salted fish and chicken fried rice.  Simple, fulfilling and you cannot get it wrong.  Prices reasonable and keeps the belly happy, so why not check it out?
author: Alicia A.

description:
This is gotta be one of the hidden treasures in Sunset. 

Highlights: crab, baked oyster, seafood tofu soup

The service was very friendly even though it's almost 10pm when we walked in. Food was served fast and fresh. Did I mention it's dirt cheap? $15 per person given the quality and quantity is a steal. 

Parking is a pain though, but that's not surprising in SF.
author: Rachel Z.

description: This place has great giant clams in a stir fry. Also a fried pork chop and tofu dish.
author: Peter K.

description:
This place has been the go-to restaurant for my family after the Dragon House on Geary closed in 2007. As several family members are vegetarian or pescatarian, Ming's Diner has turned out to be our favorite restaurant in the city. For reference, my experience has only been dine-in. 

+Vegetarian Pi-Pa Tofu: I think the English equivalent is "Dragon Balls", which is about as awful a name as you can get, but they are delicious. 
+Green onion pancakes: The best I've had in SF, though they don't fare well if not eaten straight away. 
+Salt and Pepper Shrimp: Delivered hot and delightfully delicious every time.
+Fried Rice: I have no idea which one it is, but it's a vegetarian option that includes pine nuts, some form of fake ham(?), and seaweed on top of the standard ingredients. 

-Parking around the area can be hellish. 
-It's not as clean as one would hope a restaurant to be...

Service has always been unfailingly polite and quick, and the quality of the food has always been consistently tasty.
author: Leonard C.

description:
I was driving down Taraval looking for vegetarian options, this popped up on yelp, so I parked and went in.

Straight up, I didn't want to spend $10 on a dish, but simply, that was pretty much the range. 

It wasn't too busy, there are tons of places to sit.
The server was nice, but maybe we had some communication issues as I asked for water with ice and he told me no ice... I dont know why there's no ice.

I got sweat and sour ribs - $10.
I got their dragon tofu balls - $10.

They were good and again, I kinda didn't like the price, but to be fair the portions matched. I had left overs for the lunch the next day.
author: Roger A.

description: Let me first state that the service was exceptionally helpful and very friendly when choosing my dish I really appreciated how keen he was by helping me select what I wanted on the other hand the food that we received was terrible the fish was definitely not fresh the chow fun was overcooked and the noodles were stuck together in a lumpy gravy mess the sauce was bland and the wonton soup also had no flavor pretty disappointed by this place
author: Amber J.

description: Firstly, I didn't know about the hygiene problems. But, we ate here before and it was pretty good. I needed to get dinner fast and was coming from my manicurist a few doors down. I picked up salt and pepper fried oysters and calamari, Peking duck, Mongolian beef, combination fried rice, Singaporean noodles, and Gai Lan (Chinese broccoli). Everything was delicious and fresh! Our only complaint is that the calamari became a little soggy, which really happens anyway when not eaten immediately. Reasonably priced, nice people-what's not to like??
author: Antoinette S.

description: Had my son's surprised 18th Birthday in the upper lever of this restaurant. We had about 55 guests, we pretty took over the whole 2nd floor. I met with the son's owner Alfred prior to the party. We had to go over the menu with likes and dislikes and even met his cutie son. He was very pleasant to work with and patient. He listened and answered all my annoying questions. Alfred is very friendly and accommodating of my needs.He made sure we were satisfied and happy not just with the  food but service. His staff gave up an exceptional experienced, they were kind, friendly and worked really hard to serve us. The set dinner menu were very filling and the portions were more than enough to even take home. The quality of the food was amazing and super tasty. My guests and especially my family left the restaurant with a full tummy and brag how wonderful this restaurant is. Once again, thank you Alfred and family for my making my son's party a memorable experience!!!
author: Tess C.

description:
This place has the best PORK CHOPS! Period.  

So yummy.  That's definitely their star dish that I crave for. =)
author: David W.

description:
As far as I know, there is no better place on the West Coast to throw a vegetarian Chinese banquet for your grandmother's 100th birthday. (For those of you who have to throw a lot of those.)

The place might not look like much downstairs, but there is a surprisingly nice banquet room upstairs. And in terms of vegetarian Chinese, the food is quite good; among the fake meat dishes, I particularly enjoy the fake shrimp with fruit salad. But nothing was really terrible (which can certainly happen when you go for vegetarian Chinese).

Just as an FYI, apparently the Chinese name of this place has absolutely no correlation to "Ming's Diner." But I'm not going to worry about it, so you shouldn't either.
author: Peter D.

description: This place has piss poor service! The wait service and owners have terrible attitudes. I'm Asian and I can tolerate and understand that type of attitude but this place is unbelievable. Walked in and walked right back out. Should have known! Just opened Yelp for this place and a notice pops up about poor food safety. This place needs to be closed!
author: Jessica T.

description:
worst string beans ever, salt and pepper fish without pepper, decent  potstickers.  Heavy MSG. 
Better places in the neighborhood.
author: Ann M.

description:
Zero if only yelp would let me!!!

Dad ask politely in Chinese 'how much longer will the wait be for a table'

Host lady barks back in Chinese 'you will be seated when I tell you you'll be seated'

-_- 

An hour later we're seated. After hearing the host lady b*tch and complain about us not making a reservation for 6 on a Sunday night for dinner. 

We order food and they are out of two dish...

-_-

We wait another good 45 minutes for our food.

While waiting we 

1. got to hear one of the waiter guys basically yelled at the top of his lungs, in the middle of the diner, cursing a lil host girl and her entire family b c  he did not see her serving a table and almost ran into her bc the restaurants layout is a complete mess...

2. Hear the waiter tell a table behind me how crappy the kitchen staff is and that they ran out a dish, b c they ran out of ingredients...

Food comes after 45 min...

Soup comes first. It tasted old...

The dishes...

Greasy. And someone from my group brings up the pt that every single dish looks exactly the same...

We finish dinner after 30 minutes.

Dad asked in Chinese 'will there be dessert'

Host lady responds in Chinese 'yea, of course' (except her attitude/demeanor was  more like duh! Of course)

To which it tastes like water with a lil sugar...

-__-

... ... ... No words can describe how I feel about this place. Smh
author: Catherine K.

description: I can't believe you over charged me $30.70 for crappy serving of Oxtail Stew, that tasted like corn starch and overcooked oily vegetables.  So disappointed in this place.  It's a shame you'd rip off a local wanting to support your business.
author: Steph Y.

description: Authentic Chinese cuisine. Four stars for the oxtail claypot. The oxtail is nice and tender and the sauce is full of flavor. I also ordered their chef's special, giant clams stir fry with sprouts and chives. The flavors are good except that it needed just a little more seasoning. It was a little too bland for me. The lobster noodle was good too, again a little more flavor would make it fantastic. They have live seafood so that makes up for the lack of flavors on some of the dishes.
author: Cindy T.

description: We come here every time I see my mom's parents. We come here for lunch. I mean the food is literally all MSG. I'm very thirsty even after one or two hours. Some dishes are very greasy and oily. The only good dish there is is the lamb with soft carrots. It's sort of like a stew. I'm not sure what the name is. Service is ok but not the best. And this place is really dirty in the inside. Overall it's not exactly the best restaurant to go to.
author: Wilford L.

description: I just wolfed down a reasonable amount of my chow fun and found a thick hair in it. GROSS!! And our walnut shrimp had the most bitter and weird taste ever. I had to spit it out. Whaaaaat...
author: Kenitha Y.

description: Today is Chinese New Year's day,and also my husband birthday,we did not feel like to cook ,so we decide to go outside to eat,since ming's Diner is close by and also they have the vegetarian options, it  works for the whole family vegetarian and non vegetarian.total nine of us ,they are kind of full,there no big table lift downstairs,so went upstairs,those tables might not been used for while,there are a lots of dust on the table and plates,we are all used the paper towel  to wipe our plate,we order eight plates,the food are taste pretty good,the service is little slow,we had to wait for long time to get our last dish pine nuts fried rice,it is very tasty, but it is little pretty price,it is $10 for the fried rice.
author: Mamei W.

description:
3.5 stars
I tried to dislike this place cause I've heard stories (you don't wanna know), but I can't help it cause their vegetarian dishes are SO SO BOMB. I work pretty close by, so whenever my coworkers and I want Chinese, we order from here, but only off the vegetarian menu. The vegetarian spareribs are so addicting! They taste exactly like the real thing, if not better. I've also had the fried soft tofu with enoki mushrooms and some vegetarian "chicken" dish with lotus root, which were both delicious as well. I haven't had a bad vegetarian dish here..yet. 

Service is spotty, especially around lunchtime as the construction workers come in, and they get really busy. I've seen them turn people away even when there were tables available. And my coworkers have told me that they're really stingy with their hot sauce when you order takeout. How much do hot sauce packets cost, like, ten cents?
author: Audrey T.

description:
I only come here with my bf and his family but the food never disappoints. I just shut up and let them order cuz I know it'll be good.

Get the fried flounder. It's sooo good w/ the sauce and don't forget to eat the small bones on the outer edges (seriously addicting). 

Other dishes that are worth getting off the top of my head (i've never had a bad dish):
salt + pepper pork w/ fried tofu
salt + pepper shrimp
chicken w/ the shrimp chips
seafood tofu soup (omg)
baked oysters 

The service is always friendly and quick, always refilling our tea! I read some of the negative reviews on here and maybe we're just lucky but this place is pretty damn good.
author: Alli D.

description: Our family has been coming here for years.  They have one of the best duck, so tender and flavorful! SOOOO GOOD!!!  Today we had pot stickers - they were huge and delicious, fried rice - with a mixture of shrimp, bbq pork, chicken, and vegetables, tomato beef chow mein - it was a bit on the sour side for me today, bass - I am not one for fish, so I am not a good judge for this dish, lobster - different than traditional lobster, a bit more spiced/flavored up, I think i prefer it more naked, soup - I don't know what kind but it was pretty good, and onion pancakes which are addicting!  Prices are reasonable, parking was easy street parking, and service was friendly.  I like eating here!
author: Andrea B.

description:
I have to give this place an OK rating.  Used to be a weekly diner at this place w/ the fam.  The kids used to always complain why we can't eat anywhere else, but Mr. Daniel is very talkative, gets along with our family, and we have tried so much on their menu that they can recite it to us.  For a quick appetizer, we order the Green Onion Chinese Pancake.  My favorite dish is the fried pork chops, and the fish and corn.  Also really like the sticky rice stuffed in chicken.  Takes a while for it to come out of the kitchen, but eventually it will come.

Ever since Chinese New Year's when I visited w/ the boys, this place is not as common a dining place as it used to.  The boss lady decided to let all her acquaintances pass us up in line, and we waited for a good hour, and still weren't seated.  What was suppose to be 15 min, turned into 60 min.  So for Chinese New Year, we had to take our party of 4 (party of FOUR) somewhere else.  Kept a distaste in our mouths for the restaurant.

Half of the family still went for dinners and lunches, but a new bus boy spilled a pot of tea on one of them, which might be common to new bus boys (but I don't know), so I think it was time for us to take our business elsewhere.

Nonetheless, I miss eating here, miss the food.  But there is no way I'm going back with the family.
author: Janet T.

description:
It's hard to find restaurants that offer both meat dishes and vegetarian dishes that are tasty, have no MSG, offer big portions, and are reasonably priced.  It's for these reasons that my family and I come here regularly.  The waiters/waitresses are always friendly and accommodating.  Because of the extensive menu, we could go there every week and never be bored with the food, because there are plenty of dishes to choose from.  

My only gripe would be the restrooms and the decor which could use some sprucing up.
author: Sharon W.

description:
They have a lot of vegetarian dishes to choose from. Any dish you like, they can make it vegetarian. Some of the meat food was oily and greasy, but it was still not bad.

I think it's a nice environment. Friendly people. A restaurant close by home.
author: Jade F.

description: Cheap, quality Chinese food. Cleanness could be improved, but the price is good and lots of veggie options.
author: Tracy P.

description: Came at 6 and surprised we were the only ones there. Haven't eaten here in awhile but the waiter was nice enough to recommend us some popular vegetarian dishes that were delicious and not expensive. Great service, got all our dishes around the same time even though it started getting a little busy there and LOVE the deep fried milk balls they gave us in the end :) definitely coming back in the future!
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is unique in that I must recommend the vegetarian selections, not because they're healthy, but because they are flavorful with none of the weird textures you would think of with fake meat. In fact, you can hardly tell the fake pork they use is fake!

I recommend ( from the vegetarian menu):

(+) Puffed Egg white with deep fried preserved mustard greens and pine nuts(like a stir fried omelet)
(+) Pine Nut Fried Rice( has pieces of fake spam-like protein)
(+) Vegetarian Sweet and sour spare ribs (tastes just like your original sweet and sour pork)

As far as I know this is the only Chinese restaurant around that has these vegetarian dishes, and I highly encourage them! I think you can ask the waiter to hold off on the MSG as well
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I have been eating at this place since high school; after 15+ years the food is still really delicious, while the price stayed reasonable. i love the different pork chops and seafood dishes. they even have an extensive vegetarian menu. 

it is a very typical Chinese restaurant for the locals. great good with great prices. service is good in general but may be spotty during busy weekend nights.
author: Ed L.

description: Been coming here since the early 90's and not much has changed, except for the prices. It was the same staff 20 years ago and same paint on the walls. In fact each time I come in, see the same spot of grease near the door.
author: M C.

description: This review and five stars is for dining in, and not take out.  Not impressed with take out chowmein.  What I have enjoyed here is the fried chicken stuffed with sticky rice, oxtails with XO sauce.  Looking forward to trying more things here since I've moved back to the Sunset.  Pictures here on yelp look yummy!
author: Marvella W.

description: Ming's is a decent restaurant for a family wanting to eat out. But having eaten here a few times, it's a hit and miss on quality, probably due to different cooks. I'll say they have consistently served sizeable portions, and the waiter is very amicable. Of special note is their Dragon Balls & Broccoli, made of seasoned tofu, from their vegetarian menu.
author: Cliff W.

description:
I came here for dinner with my family, and we arrived at 6pm.  There was only 1 table with customers.  Since we were a huge party, we were told to sit on the second floor.

At first, we did not receive any service at all!  I had to walk downstairs to grab menus for my family after we waited 5 minutes.  After 10 more minutes of waiting, finally 1 server came to our table.  My family decided to order 8 dishes to try.

I think its pretty cool that we were given complimentary 'green onion pancake' and 'beef soup' while we waited for our main dishes.  The pancake was crispy but a bit oily.  The soup was ok.  

We ordered the following dishes:

1. fried tofu balls with broccoli and enoki mushrooms - the fried tofu balls was very tasty.  It was not bland, and I thought there was ham mixed inside the ball.

2. fried flounder - The flounder is fried till its very crispy!  Then soy sauce is poured on top of it.  The fish was very good and not dry.

3. stir fry spinach - it was bland, so I didn't like it

4. quail claypot - I didn't try this

5. steamed black bass - the fish was super small!  It was so tiny that 1 person can totally finish this.  I didn't try this either.

6. veggie claypot - there was various types of tofu in here.  I liked this dish

7. seafood claypot - I didn't try this dish

8. soy sauce chicken - the chicken was diced up into many tiny pieces.  The chicken was tender and it tasted great with the sauce.

After all the dishes came out, we really didn't see the server anymore.  To get any service, we literally had to walk downstairs to get the waiter.  We were given complimentary 'red bean dessert'.  This was good and not too sweet.

Overall, Ming's Diner has ok Chinese food.  I found a lot of the dishes to be a bit oily.  I was surprised that when we left, the place was very packed with customers.
author: Rita V.

description:
I discovered Ming's Diner as I walked down Taraval in search of a café with free WiFi.  I was a bit puzzled by the name since I had never been to a Chinese diner before and decided to give it a try.  Everything on the lunch menu was in the $5-6 range so I decided it was easily worth a try and was pretty happy to be getting out of the cold weather just beyond the doors of the diner.

There were many specials on the menu but I craved beef chow fun on this especially chilly San Francisco day.  Before my entrée arrived, I was served a large bowl of chicken soup with Chinese spices.  It was extremely invigorating and warmed my body as I prepared to scarf down some pan fried noodles.  Although not exceptional, the beef chow fun was pretty good and about par for the course of what you might expect for $5.  The portion size was extremely impressive and I actually found myself having trouble finishing it and even considered taking it home for dinner.  However, knowing I would be heading to an internet café afterward to get some work done, I persevered and was able to finish every last bite.

Ming's is definitely a great place to grab lunch if you happen to be in the Sunset.  The prices are right, the portions are huge, and you just can't beat the quick and upbeat service, especially considering that it's just one of those "cheap Chinese places".  In fact, it's not just one of those "cheap Chinese places" and stands on its own for all of the reasons previously listed and I might just be dropping by for lunch again tomorrow.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Great chicken, moist with crispy roasted skin. Dungeoness crab has a smokey caramelly sauce. Service is stretched with one main waiter, but efficient enough.
author: E. W.

description:
This is my extended fam's regular spot for family dinners. My grandma likes Ming's because the servers are friendly and the food is pretty good and cheap. 

We always end up ordering the green onion pancakes, shredded salt baked chicken, preserved salted fish with tofu claypot, garlic stir-fried with snow pea pods, walnut prawns, and a couple of other dishes. We always get these dishes because they're consistently good. 

Ming's is pretty packed on the weekends, so I highly suggest that you make reservations, even for small groups of 4.
author: Diana C.

description: More than 30mins to prepare my take out with only 4 table of customers.  I only ordered one rice plate. Unacceptable
author: Harry Y.

description:
This is for their to-go service only.

I walked in and there was only 3 tables occupied but I wasn't there to dine in. I called in 30m ago to order a plate to go. Two waiters were standing around not doing anything. They didn't even say Hi or How can I help you! I was standing there for about 5m until a lady walks out and ask me what I needed. I paid for my food and walked out. 

Service is -100. The 1 star is mandatory.
author: Serena F.

description: Great restaurant for a great price. Food is kind of greasy but what Chinese food isn't?
author: Jonathan L.

description:
HANDS DOWN best authentic Chinese food in the Bay Area. Everything's incredibly cheap but the portions are huge. Not to mention the tea and white rice are free. The vegetarian food here is delicious. My grandma's Buddhist temple orders from here all the time. Of course, the seafood is as well. I recommend ordering the salt and pepper crab (DA BOMB crunchy deep fried outside). The fish and shrimp are really fresh. You can even point to which fish you want in the tanks. 

The mah poh tofu (which isn't on the menu, but if you tell the female waiter, she'll understand) and the peking duck i tried during a family dinner was also very tasty.  

The owners of the place are really nice. They don't come out of the kitchen very often since the owner is the main chef, but they give out a lot of freebies. I talked to one of the waiters who gave me some eggettes for dessert (out of the blue because since when do chinese restaurants serve eggettes?) and he said the owners sometimes make random sweets and appetizers in the kitchen when they have time and give them to customers for free. Such a shame people don't know this and complain when they aren't given those same complimentary french fries, tempura or eggettes SMH.

Anyways, I love love love this place. I get take out here all the time. Definitely one of my favorites.
author: Iris W.

description: I come here every year for Christmas because my mom is vegetarian. The food is decent and I think every thing is quite tasty. They have quite a good variety of vegetarian dishes and they can make almost any dish in vegetarian style. They have large portions and good pricing. Hope to come back again!
author: Gary Y.

description:
This place is like hole in a wall. I can always rely on Ming's for fast, greasy and delicious Chinese food. The portion is huge and it's cheap. A few of my favorite dishes from them are the Saucey Beef Chow Fun, Salt & Pepper Pork Ribs with Tofu, and their Clay Pot Tofu & Fish Fillet. 

The waiters are usually pretty quick and friendly even when they get busy on the weekend. Even when you're seated upstair, they constantly come and check on you.
author: Mandy C.

description:
We have been to this place 3 times and it just gets better and better every time. For starters, this place has a large selection and reasonable price, like most other Chinese restaurants out there. Taste is the biggest factor that differentiates this place from most other Chinese restaurants out there. 

The other specialty about this place is their vegetarian menu which looks like a regular menu. The magic with their vegetarian food is that they taste as much like meat as one could possibly imagine. At least I had trouble telling the difference between a meat and vegetable even though I knew the food was really made up of vegetables. 

Overall, excellent place for frequent visiting.
author: Jun W.

description:
big portions for cheap! who can say no to that??  think again....

Beef Chow Fun
- i love beef chow fun. my mother ate beef chow fun every day when she was pregnant with me.  i crave beef chow fun all the time but i allow myself to get it once a year.  beef chow fun should be at the very least, well flavored, but over here all i can taste is **BURNED GREASE**.  even i could not forgive this place for messing up chowfun to a person who is not picky about it

Mongolian Beef
- chunks of meat dipped in some soysauce and thrown in a vat of oil with some onions...this might have been the least impressive mongolian beef it has been my displeasure to try

House Special Fried Rice
~98% rice
~2% yesterday's leftover dried out cha siu, with 2 pieces of shrimp thrown in for show

Shanghai Crispy Noodles
- this was the star of the show, the sauce was more flavorful than the other dishes, and you can taste the browned garlic on the bok choi and carrots.  the chicken meat was over-corn-starched, however

we ended up with a lot of leftovers - i certainly was not going to be the one to take them home.   
it has been over 4 hours and i am still feeling the thirst of the MSG they put into the bland food.

my impression: this restaurant puts quantity over quality, so if you are looking for cheap [greasy, bland, MSG-laden] dishes, this is the place to be
author: Tina A.

description: Walking into Ming's, you'd think it's like every other Chinese restaurant around.  The decor is decent but better than most although leaving more to be desired like the rest.  My family likes this place and has been coming here for years. We get good friendly service, and the food is damn good Cantonese style food.  What separates them from the rest is the minimal grease in most all the dishes.  Chow fun and pan- fried chow mein for instance is usually ridden with grease.  -not at Ming's though!  I also like the house soup they serve at the beginning of every meal.  It's a hearty, clear beef broth with what looks like some artichoke in it.  Yes, it sounds weird, but it's actually a  satisfying start to a yummy meal.  The price is right too.  Two heaping dishes of chow mein and one of chow fun all for a whopping $20!  Leave satisfied and hardly a dent to your wallet!  This is an excellent lunch spot!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Best bang for the buck in the Sunset for authentic Cantonese food. Black bean chow fun is one of my favorite here. Free soup is a bonus too. It's your typical greasy Chinese restaurant. Not the cleanest and the decor, furniture is old and outdated. But if you're looking to satisfy a monster appetite for less than $10 per person this us the place.
author: C C.

description: This place is horrible. Came here to order take out (just vegetarian dishes) and they took 30-40 minutes. Wtf??? And it wasn't even busy in the restaurant. Supposedly they only had one chef, but still we only ordered vegetarian food come on....when the food finally came they only gave us 6 dishes when we originally placed an order for 8. Sigh, seems like they can't do anything right.
author: Diane L.

description: I've been coming here since I was a teenager for family dinners . Price is reasonable and we always order the set menus and maybe add a couple of dishes.  . The service is fast and if your in the area and need something quick I would come here . It can get busy but most of the time no . I love their onion pancake, and also their veggie dishes. If you are a vegetarian this is the place for you, they have really good dishes .
author: Tiffany K.

description: Gotta say they aren't the cleanest place. The place feels a bit out dated and you may find a few bugs on your outing. Other than that, the food is pretty good. It's one of my favorite family-owned Chinese restaurants that aren't overly priced.
author: Jess W.

description:
After reading a few reviews on this place, I discovered that many ABC's (American Born Chinese!) like me have memories of this place growing up.  Whether it be good or bad, many of those memories follow the lines of themselves when they were younger sitting at a table of  two or more generations of their family and sharing a meal together.  I recall eating here with my family when we visited my great grandmother who used to live in the area.  Among those times we ate here, I can recall other tables of the same dynamic of son/daughter, mother/father, grandmother/father, and maybe a great grandmother/father added in there as in my case.  This place reminds me of those memories as they were fond and happy times.  That was a time where only play was in constant thought and responsibility was out of the picture.

Now I'm all grown up and I still come here time to time.  I eat here less for dinner, rather come here for lunch, or get lunch take out.  I usually order entrees like Hong Kong style pan fried noodles, chicken (Because I already eat too much beef) chow fun, or Singapore noodles.  These are all items typical of an ABC.  The food here is on the greasy side at times even when you ask them to cut down on it.  The MSG is obvious; let's not kid ourselves.  Now if you take those two things out, greasy and MSG, out of the equation which shouldn't be a surprise for you as a customer anyway, the food is unquestionably good for their prices.  It's not dirt cheap, but its close.  The portions are a very good size.   

The service is what you call "to the point".  The servers with their black vests that should have been dry-cleaned a decade ago are quite abrasive, but they're honest.  They'll offer a suggestion sometimes, and the veteran waiter of the group is pretty funny.  He's an older gentleman with a slender build and loud voice.  You can't miss him.  I don't know how long this group of workers has been together, but it seems like a while.  Also, if you don't speak Cantonese (or Chingrish in my case), ordering shouldn't be a real problem.        

I would recommend these two things since these two are personal favorites of mine from here: "fried sticky rice chicken" and their "one fish two style dish combo".  You're wondering why I have these in quotes.  It's because I don't know the English translation, but I'm sure if you use the following descriptions, they'll know what to make for you.  The sticky rice chicken comes in a form of an actual whole fried chicken with sticky rice sandwiched between the crispy skin above and the meat of the chicken on the bottom.  The first sight of the presentation will catch your eye.  Not every Cantonese restaurant may have it, and this place makes it pretty good.  The other involves a rock cod (or any other fish) special many other restaurants have as well that uses one fish and allows you to customize how they are cooked into two entrees.  They don't make it the best, but I enjoy it every time I get it. 

Are you looking for old school home style Cantonese food and you're in the Sunset area?  This is the place.  The food, feel, and look of everything in the restaurant fits the bill of an old school Cantonese restaurant.
author: Arnold T.

description:
Very reasonable prices, and big portions. The taste is also right on as greasy Chinese food (I'm Chinese and I've eaten a LOT of Chinese food in my life). There really isn't any other kind. I was in a party of five, and paid less than $40 for dinner for everybody. We had leftovers to take home for lunch the next day. Enough said.

I love the deep fried salt and pepper pork chops and tofu. I can eat that all day if I don't have to worry about clogged arteries. Other dishes are also tasty.

The service is also very friendly. This isn't a place to take people if you wanna impress them with touristy crap. This is pretty authentic Chinese food and it's not fancy. I've been there more than once and will definitely go back again.
author: Sara K.

description:
I love family style Asian restaurants!

I havent been to too many authentic Chinese family restaurants, only Sam Woo and Dong Khanh in So Cal so I dont have much to compare to, but Ming's was good to me! My friend's mom ordered everything in Cantonese and I had no clue that we were in for a feast. There was walnut shrimp, crispy noodles, fried pork ribs, tofu balls, vegetable stir fry, shrimp fried rice, and a lot more that I cant recall. needless to say i was stuffed and satisfied. 

this place isnt ritzy but it serves good portions of chinese classics. i wouldnt go here without a good sized group of people, and a Chinese person. 

I'd definitely come back if I'm ever in Sunset again.
author: Ngan T.

description: This place has okay food, but horrible service. The waiters and hostess are just plain rude and my family has not gone there for years now even though we live nearby.
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
Many of my Cantonese friend's family as well as my own frequent Ming's fairly often. They've had the same staff for many years (I'm assuming it is a family business), and they are all extremely friendly and nice. They have excellent customer service, always bringing out food prompt and quick on refills of tea. The staff always thanks you for coming enthusiastically, which is just a nice touch in my opinion.

The food is standard Cantonese family style dining. Like some others have said they are supposed to serve good vegetarian dishes like the sign says, but overall they serve a wide variety of standard Cantonese dishes - all of them, even the vegetarian of high quality.

My family just went here last night and we had a set menu for $80 plus maybe two dishes al la carte. The bill came out to about $100 I think for 9 people - we had oysters, black bean clams, fried shrimp, a sizzling beef platter, scallops with vegetables, oxtail stew (very good), a whole crab dish, and I think another dish or so that elludes my memory right now. The portions are EXTREMELY generous I must add, and although our party killed the entire meal - we could have had leftovers... but me, my dad, and grandpa were hungry white men with large appetites!

I would definitely take any of my friends to this place for dinner. My family has been here for lunch too, and it is just as good.

As people have recommended, this place has the best value for large groups (at least 4, recommended more) because the "set menus" are the best value. Order off the set menu for your large party and order some additional dishes here and there to add to it if you'd like. You won't be disappointed.

I'd give this place 4.5/5 stars if I could. I'm very picky about my 5 star ratings, but Ming's is one of the places that comes close. I suppose if Ming's were a shade better decorated, I'd give it the 5 stars but it's a neighborhood family restaurant - not exactly fine dining, so leave the dress clothes at home and enjoy the most authentic and delicious Cantonese family restaurant food money can buy in San Francisco.
author: Doug R.

description:
This place isn't too bad. The food can be too salty sometimes but generally not too bad. But I would have to say that the one Seafood special meal is a bargain at $65. The crab, clams, oysters, seafood soup, shrimp, and fish are pretty good.

I've tried other things on the menu - and it's really hit or miss.
They offered us a Lingcod claypot special once that wasn't on the menu and that was awesome.

Another time - we ordered salted fish rice and my wife and me ended up with bad stomach aches.
author: Richard C.

description:
A Chinese friend and I checked this place out the other day.  The waiter quickly made a point of telling us about the daily specials, which was fine.  But, when we didn't order them, he got mad.  When I asked him what were the items on the totally written in Chinese menu, he got really mad, said "I can't help you", and quickly walked away.

They had house soup which I thought was ok.

I ordered the tomato beef chow mein which neither of us liked.  It had a very thick Chef Boyardee  like sauce - except chef Boyardee tastes better.  No nice slices of fresh tomato, green peppers, or onion.  Truthfully, one of the worst tomato beef chow meins I ever had.

My friend ordered chicken with tender greens.  This was much, much, better.  In fact, it was good and tasty.  I would order that dish again

I should add there was a woman server there that seemed to be much more pleasant than the man.  BTW, he also seemed to be yelling and scolding a family group that did speak Chinese.

I might try Ming's one more time to give it another chance, but I think 8 Immortals up the street is much better.  It is a lot more crowded, but what does that tell you?
author: Marty C.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars.
The food was fairly solid and actually had an exceptional vegetarian selection.

* Buddah Delight was vegetarian variety wrapped in bean curd tofu skin. It was very tasty and looked very pleasing. 
* Sizzling Beef was a big oily. I would put a pass on this one next time.
* Beef Ho Fun was pretty decent. Not to oily. Portional beef to ho fun amount.
* Chicken with Eggplant Clay Pot was delish. Smelled good when it arrived at the table and went very well with rice. It was a little saucy, but went perfectly with rice.
* Dragonball was a fried tofu ball with mixed vegetables inside. It looked very appealing because the tofu balls were fried and lined up around the dish. However, the taste was pretty mellow. The tofu really mellowed out the dish eventhough there was some gravy on the dish. Too bad. But not sure how dish could be better. For a vegetarian tofu dish, it is pretty good.
* Shrimp and Eggs Omelete was pretty homemade looking. 
* Vegetarian Sweet and Sour Pork was my most disappointed dish. The vegetarian sweet and sour porks came in little fried balls. I ate one and it just tasted odd to me. Of all the dishes we ate, I was least estatic about this one. I would definitely pass on this dish and try something else next time.

Overall, I was fairly pleased with the chinese dinner. I really liked their additional vegetarian menu selections and will go back to try other dishes.
author: Janice T.

description:
One of the best places to get Chinese vegetarian food. They also provide non-vegetarian food. 

My favorites are the dragon balls and the lettuce wraps. You also get free tee.
author: Vlad P.

description: I give them 3.5 stars. I came for a vegetarian lunch after a funeral and it was really good for all vegetarian food! I minus .5 stars only because of the bad service and dude waiter, take a shower or wear deodarant please!
author: Karen T.

description:
I totally have to downgrade them after the crappy service they gave us.  I really do think they are more attentive when you order one of their expensive set dinners (wo choy).  Last time we went, we ordered ala cart and they virtually ignored us!  Geez, I know we're not shelling out $168 for  a set dinner but our order wasn't too shabby either (it was about $100+).

To add insult to injury, they overcharged us for white rice.  Not only did they charge our little kiddies (who quite frankly can only eat 1/8" bowl of rice) they charged us for 10 people -- we had 9 in the party including our little totlets.  

Bad bad thing!  The last time someone ripped us off with the rice money (I'm looking at you Superior Palace), they lost our business.

Ming's just lost our business!
author: Wendy H.

description: Decent Chinese restaurant. Ordered the honey walnut shrimp, rock cod with tofu, vegetables and sweet and sour pork. A little on the expensive side for the dinner while the portions weren't super generous.
author: Wilson T.

description: this place isn't the cleanest nor the friendliest... but the dishes are huge and delish! it is completely chinese style! i'd prefer this over koi palace ANYDAY! and besides, you won't be paying an arm and a leg for mediocre chinese food. everytime we have a huge family gathering, we'll go to Ming's for dinner. make sure reservations are made because they get packed pretty much by 6:30pm on the weekends!
author: Ann T.

description:
Visiting family here and they brought us to this Chinese very casual box-type restaurant for lunch.  Parking is available in the streets. 

The noodles are delicious particularly the beef chow fun.  My takeaway of this place is noodles - all sorts at very affordable prices.
author: Salena M.

description:
One of my family's standards in the Outer Sunset.  We come here for most of our family celebrations.  The food is good, they accommodate our large family and it's classic cantonese food.      

The joint:  Normal over packed loud chinese joint.  They did remodel so there is a fresh coat of peachy pink on the walls! :D

The food:  Good consistent chinese food.  We had the fried chicken, the peppered steak, the squab, the salt pepper shrimp, the 'jai", the house soup, sweet and sour pork, the pea sprouts.  It was all good.  The fried chicken is always very tender and yummy.  The Peppered steak was a little tough but flavorful.  The Squab is one of my fav dishes but could be better.  Everything else was good but nothing spectacular.  

The service:  Friendly and energetic.  The one older waiter is an absolute red bull addict.  Every single time we come here... and we come here alot, this guy is ON!  He's got more energy than my 1 year old nephew.  He's there with the order, with the extra napkins, with the water, the tea.
author: Marie L.

description:
For being in predominantly Chinese part of the city, I just don't know how the food could be that bad. The flavors didn't go well together, some of my dishes were too salty, and I had a stomach ache after. I have a pretty strong stomach and VERY RARELY get stomach aches, but Ming's found a way to cramp it up. My date, who is Chinese, also agreed and also had a stomach ache.

Service is mean. As I was standing up to get my wallet from my back pocket, our server looked at me and said in a manner that can be described as "curt," "Tip!" while pointing down at the table. "Excuse me?" I replied. "Don't forget to tip," he answered, this time using a full sentence. Of course I was going to tip - that's why I was standing up. I should've left right there, but I tossed $2 on the table out of guilt and left.

The restaurant is a mess. Just look at the pictures of it from the outside: clearly, appearance also means little to this establishment.

If you're in this part of the Sunset and you're looking for Chinese food, head up to Irving Street. Practically anything there will be better.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant, i've been eating there for 15 years!!! The owners are very nice, food is always fabulous and the service is FAST & courteous ! My favorite dishes that i eat here are generally not available at any other restaurants. I usually start off like this...

Course 1: Onion Pancakes- EXCELLENT!
Course 2: Vegetarian Yu Soong Yu Lok- Eggwhites, pinenuts, carrots, vegetarian spam with mustard greens- Very healthy and delicious 
Course 3: 3 Stuffed Treasures- stuffed eggplant, stuffed mushroom and stuffed tofu (w/ shrimp paste) topped with garlic black bean sauce.
Course 4: Beef Chow Fun- Can't get wrong here
Course 5: Singapore fried Rice Noodle- Curry flavor, loaded with shrimp, chicken and bbq pork!
Course 6: Fried Flounder- Nice and crispy
Course 7: Mandarin Pork Ribs- WAY BETTER THAN SWEET AND SOUR PORK!!!! My family's all time favorite and go to dish. 

*Bonus* Complimentary soup and Sweet bean soup for dessert :)
author: Candy T.

description:
Ew with a side of barf.

I live down the street from this pace, and have always been curious as to how it was.  Well one day I was craving some Chow Mien and wanted to either order in or get it somewhere within walking.  Since I had never had Ming's before I decided to give it a shot and see how their chow mien was.  And it was sucky, sucky pan fried noodle slop.  Bland, flavorless, boring noodles.

My  bf says I got the wrong thing.  But hes retarded.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Last Friday, Mike Bauer from sfgate (no relation to Jive Bauer of 24 "Sushi") was hopping mad about a blog he read about Mel's Diner SF offering 20% discount off in return for customers writing yelp reviews in hopes of raising their 2.5 average score. Dat no ethical...

On the west side of town, Ming's Diner (no relation to Mel's) on Taraval and 31st, is overflowing to the brim with A$Ns all over on a Saturday night. And Ming isn't giving two $hit$ about what the net thinks of him or his food or service. 

Yes, we came here for the vegetarian fare. But we didn't know that it was only 38 items allocated to a Vegetarian Special section, of a multi page menu that catered mostly to meatatarians. They have seafood too, including fresh from the tanks of lobster, spot prawns, dungeoness crab, and hmmmm riddle me this...live eels that looked pretty pi$$ed they were the only fresh fish rep.

And even the vegetarian menu looked suspect.... the English translation looked like it was put together from various meatatarian cla$$ic$...

like

Walnut Prawn

Shark's Fin Soup (OK before you flame, it's probably bean thread noodles, aka vegan shark fin. Evil thought, but not so evil on the environment.....where's vegan foie gras, vegan bluefin toro, or vegan panda, vegan scorpion?!)

So this raises my point that Chinese vegetarian/vegan, is designed in such a way to appeal to the taste of meatatarians (hence the faux meat looking dishes), so should they find the need to transition to a vegetable diet, that they can do so a bit easier via this means. If you are a stark Buddhist vegan type, or prefer a salad, or some Ubuntu Green Millinium Falcon Star Wars organic slow food mofo vegan, this is probably not the place for you.

Although Jillian from the Bachelorette made the hardest decisions in her life, i.e. figuring out what girth and firmness of sausage she wants to hold on to for another episode, we didn't want to fall into that brain draining mode with the menu ourselves, so we defaulted to our waiter and asked what he recommended from this expansive lineup.  

#122. Pei Pa Tofu (Dragon Balls) (seasoned tofu balls) and Broccoli - $7.75

#147 - Sahng Gun Mun Dsap Wui Bo (House Special Combination Vegetarian Clay Pot) - $7.95

Fortunately 122 did not come with Akira Toriyama's assortment of characters like Son Goku and friends, nor did the fried stuffed tofu look anything like golden spheres with numbered stars on them (where if you gather the set a dragon will come out and grant you a wish, ala Dragonball Z style). But it did look like authentic pei pa tofu (where the original receipe has meat and eggs in it).

In short

122) - damn good and best value for the money. I lost count but there were around 12 oblong shaped fried stuffed tofus. The inside was soft, like a quiche but not eggy, with chunks of faux (vegan) ham and a few other things. Topped with a flavored corn starch thickened sauce, with broccoli and enoki mushrooms. Very labor intensive to make and at $8, this is a $un$et A$N cheapne$$ bargain of epic proportion$, and making it the most ordered dish off the vegetarian menu

147) - This clay pot was a mish mash of stuff, very complicated yet simple. And freakin delish. Bean thread noodles, vegan squid, vegan pork intestines, vegan preserved meat (that were fugly chunks of taro root), vegan fishballs (yummay), mushrooms, wheat gluten (mien jien) cut to look like darkened fried dough sticks bits, vegan shrimp (they even painted the stripes and made it curve!), napa cabbage. No animals or sealife were harmed for the making of 147, but damn if the faux stuff is this good, I wonder what the real stuff is like!

Ming's looks like a dump on the outside, but inside is actually quite clean and neat. Service is very spotty, especially when it is busy, so don't be too surprised that people arriving after you may get their food before you (depends on what is ordered).

We also got comp'd the house soup, very typical Cantonese style (real pork bones, veg, and Chinese herbs) almost like a clear broth, typical good solid Taraval Sunset Chinese restaurant standard (free and decent). And house dessert was green bean soup (on the sweet side, but good flavor and tasty green beans). 

Hint to the restaurant entrepreneurs....open up one o' these in the Peninsula, skip opening some new Northern trendy Chinese place...
author: Ken K.

description: I've been here several times dining in as well as ordering takeout. The food is good, though the prices here on help is very misleading. For example, the crab with ginger and scallion shows $16 on the menu, but it's actually $30. All the prices are much higher than what the website shows.
author: L. Y.

description:
Of all the variety that San Francisco has to offer a vegetarian, some of my favorite restaurants happen to be the unpretentious, family run Chinese joints.  Ming's Diner is no exception.

While they don't specialize in vegetarian cuisine, I like Ming's for advertising that they actually do cater to veg heads, as opposed to surprisingly find that they serve meat analogues by skimming through the menu.  (Contrary to other reviews, the veg menu includes english translations.)  

Their fried rice is like crack.  It is addicting.  Throw pine nuts into the mix, and it's a cut above your ordinary fried rice.  It reminds me of Enjoy Vegetarian's House Special, fake ham and all.  I've become partial to their "spareribs", both salt and pepper, and sweet and sour.  I will admit that their faux meat is not the best--it's a lil on the tough side--but the crispy fried outer shell is its redeeming quality.  The walnut prawns are next on my hit list of items to try.  Everything on the menu sounds delicious and unique; they don't just offer the usual sweet and sour/sesame chicken.

I can't speak for their regular (read: meat) menu, but the place never seems to be empty, never short of Chinese diners.  That has to say something towards the quality of the food.  But everyone, regardless of dietary preferences, can dine in perfect harmony here.  I'm sure it helps to be able to speak the language and look the part for better service, so I stick with take out to reduce any chance of getting a reduction in service by dining in.

It's a good ending point for my longer runs; I, otherwise, wouldn't make the trek out here--at least, not regularly.  But when all you're craving is some down home Chinese food for those cold, foggy days, Ming's hits the spot.
author: Marsha Z.

description: My family comes here all the time for birthday and various celebrations.  We went here last night and surprisingly my uncle ordered from the vegetarian menu.  Did you know they was a completely separate menu?  Well, I didn't.  But it was sooo good!  I was super impressed by a bunch of the dishes. The app they ordered had fried taro (yum), some kind of fried seaweed thing that tasted like fried sushi.  Some of the dishes were kind of weird.  We had fake sea bass and that was kinda interesting but it wasn't bad.  The consistency reminded me of bean curd so maybe that's what it was made out of.  Overall, I was overly satisfied and happy I got to try some new dishes
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Um, more like 0 stars.

First off, my BF went to the bathroom and there was urine all over the toilet.  Not a dry spot on the toilet.  No toilet liners to be found either.  Disgusting.

Second, he had diarrhea due to their food.  In addition, I was belching for a few days after eating their food.

Their staff needs some training on friendliness, communication and just overall restaurant etiquette.  Kinda Asian-ghetto style.

Last, but certainly not least, they have SHARK FIN SOUP on their menu.  That's just disgraceful!  

I will tell anyone who will listen why they shouldn't eat there.
author: Gigi F.

description: Had some great sweet and sour chicken, beef chow fun and egg rolls with my brother. If your in the area I'd recommend it, I live right near this resturaunt and will deffinitely be back again.
author: Meghan M.

description: Everytime I come back home I have to visit here. I don't come here for the service, I come here for the food. Some of my favs are the ox tail stew (the sauce tastes great with rice), salt and pepper spare rib and tofu, honey walnut shrimp, and Gingdo spare ribs. I'm giving this place four stars instead of five because they raised their price a little bit.
author: Allison N.

description:
Their food is alright.

Bet I definitely lost my appetite when I saw a cockroach in the bathroom.
author: Tina C.

description:
Classic Cantonese family fare that satisfy both omnivores and vegetarians.  Being from a family with both vegetarians and omnivores, this is a great place for everyone. They have both a regular menu and a vegetarian menu.  The vegetarian menu is pretty extensive and has really special Chinese vegetarian dishes.  My favorite is their vegetarian lettuce wrap which comes will the filling which and you use a fresh lettuce leaf to wrap.  

Waiters are always nice and funny.  They give you HUGE portions for the price.  Great for groups and family dinners.
author: Teresa C.

description: It been my family goto Chinese restaurant when we are in San Francisco. they have the best ret ox tail red wine clay pot in town.
author: Gazzle T.

description:
I like getting Ming's for takeout because the L stops right at the intersection, and if I call in ahead of time, my food's already packed, ready to be paid for.

It gets really busy for dinner, even on weekdays, so takeout on those days might take 30-40 minutes.  My favorites are the ginger and scallion noodles and honey walnut shrimp, mm!
author: Min H.

description:
Not the best seafood pan fried noodle but for under $11 for 2 BIG portions of noodles (can feed 2 people for lunch AND dinner) it's pretty decent.



**not the best customer service you can ask for but I had food to go =P







That is all.
author: Tracy A.

description: This place is a staple for our family.  If we go here, it's usually for lunch on Sunday, with either friends or takeout.  They make a really good Yee Foo Won Ton (Fried Won Ton Soup) and Galay Fonkay Gnow Yok Geen Mein (Curry Tomato Beef Pan Fried Noodles 咖哩番茄牛肉). Also we typically get the Wet Chow Fun with Black Bean Sauce (See Jup Gnow Ha Sup Chow) or the Dry Fried Pepper Chow Fun (See Jew Gnow Ha). The fried pepper pork chops are also quite tasty.  The service isn't so good, but we don't come here to be waited on - in fact, you get that old "thumb in your water" kind of service. Sometimes we get a waiter that is impatient because we're indecisive, or (he thinks) we order too much.  Sometimes we get our regular guy that already knows what we want. We come here for the food, and the fact that's it's not expensive, but isn't not really cheap either. Oh, and the ice maker is working so you can actually get "Bing Sui" (冰水).
author: Alan Y.

description:
First impression - Food okay. Its cheap. For $5 bucks per person @ lunch, ou get tea, the house soup (I got chicken feet stewed in ginseng), beef chow fun (not sure that would called vegetarian). 

Service I got was good - not like going to Il Fornaio. But sufficient. Wait Staff listened to our requests. Provided extra napkins.

Cavaet - its not a fancy place. many of the neighborhood folk enjoy a simple meal based on what I saw.
author: Johnson H.

description:
Ming's has become a regular fave of my Cantonese family so I have a soft spot for this place. I've eaten here over a dozen times now and the food is consistently good if you know what to order. I think it's funny that this place is supposed to be a vegetarian place because some of their non-vegetarian items are super-yum. 

Since my family eats here, we usually order in Canto for at least 8 people, and thus start off with the set menu. As any person is familiar with ordering at a Chinese restaurant, it's all about using the set menu as a base for what you want to order. These items are usually the most commonly prepared, thus you can expect the freshest ingredients. Building off the set menu, we usually add or substitute the following items:

-deep fried fish (my all-time fave at this place! you can eat the bones too.)
-oxtail stew
-vegetarian stew in claypot
-salty fish and chicken tofu
-deep fried squab

Don't bother with ordering any Americanized Cantonese food here. If you want that, go elsewhere. The price is reasonable for the amount of food you get (especially if you order the specials). The dishes are very often made with fresh ingredients and the servers will tell you what is fresh and good if you ask them to make recommendations. 

The servers all speak Canto so bust it out if you can for super-good service. (My fave server is super loud and basically yells across the room to the other servers when he communicates. He also speaks terrific broken English so don't be afraid of the loud Chinese man.) It's also good to make reservations ahead of time, especially during Chinese holidays and weekends. Otherwise your wait will be at least an hour long. Another alternative is to order out, which I see customers doing all the time. Parking takes a bit of effort, but you're in SF after all. What the heck do you expect?

One other terrific tidbit: they put a two-top in the ladies' room so it's really easy to change your baby's diaper if you need to.
author: Dawn L.

description:
It took me a while to realize that Ming's had a vegetarian menu.  The waiter won't give it to you automatically, so you have to ask for it or pick it up at the front (it's yellow).  It's also all in Chinese!  If you're like me, and can't read Chinese, don't worry.  

Ask for the vegetarian shrimp with walnuts, the fried tofu balls w/vegetables (the tofu is mixed with bits of veggies and fake meat), buddha's delight (veggies wrapped over with bean curd), #1 chicken something...or ask one of the waiters to recommend some dishes for you. 

The sauteed fish dishes are also pretty good...though sometimes I feel there are too many veggies.  

Not only is the food good, but its at a location where parking is relatively easy to find.  The place often has a few tables seated with families who often bring elderly folk with them.  Oyeah, and the seafood/vegetarian combination specialty makes this place convenient for family with different dietary preferences to eat together.
author: M K.

description: The food here was ok and the service about the same. I don't know if it's a cultural thing but for some reason the waiters here think that it's perfectly ok to sit down, eat and watch tv while simultaneously watching over your table. Personally, I find this to be very unprofessional. One thing I was amazed by was the size of the oysters here, they were huge! The steamed crab served with garlic butter was actually very good. Overall, my experience was ok, nothing special, probably won't be returning.
author: Dante C.

description:
3.5 stars

I think others have stated this, it's not really a stereotypical diner =P.
I'm not that fond of Chinese food mainly because I'm quite sick of eating it for so long (I'm Chinese btw) and going into Chinatown's restaurants for inspection during one of my internships really made Chinese food unappealing, however Ming's Diner has re-enticed my taste buds for Chinese food.  I have to admit their food was good, but there was A LOT of food, so much that we couldn't finish and had leftovers for days.

We came here for a co-worker's farewell party on the second floor, yes they have a second floor.  We ordered from the set menu and apparently 2 extra dishes... it was a good mistake.  The good part was, we had A LOT of food and food kept coming in big dishes.  The bad part was, we all didn't finish the food and ended up packing it up.  The service was pretty accommodating for all of us.  Their specialty is definitely the seafood and they have this cool stuffed sticky rice chicken - a deboned chicken stuffed with yummy sticky rice -- definitely cool.  However, I do advise that if you order the stuffed chicken, be so to call in a few days prior and don't order so much food when you eat dinner that day... because that chicken stuffs you good.
author: Natalie G.

description:
encompasses everything a sf cantonese restaurant should be. Good food, cheap prices.

everythings good here. ya know its the shiz cuz all the construction workers eat there lunch here.
author: Garrett W.

description: Fast service, great prices, and all of the dishes are always tasty and well-prepared.
author: Wilbur C.

description:
So the service is not five-star first class. Who cares? What's great about Ming's Diner is the fantastic food. Authentic as could be, despite the misleading name--this is no Dennys.

Arguably some of the best Chinese I've had in the city, a refreshing change from the McDonalds style Tenderloin Chinese fare or the countless watered-down tourists traps in Chinatown.
