Whenever I eat here I am always the only non-Chinese person. Always a great sign. This is where the locals come for lunch and big family dinners.

The prices are unbeatable in terms of dining in the city. The prawns, lemon chicken, and chow mein is fantastic. ALL of the pork dishes are fantastic, as expected. I couldn't reccommend one dish over another. The thing to do here is go with a group, order a couple of main dishes, and have everyone dig in!

I did try to call here for delivery, but too much was lost in translation. I'm still working on finding someone fluent in Chinese to do this for me.
author: Sara D.

description:
This place used to be really good. I mean it. I literally live around the corner. I've been coming here for over 10 years, and during that time, it was great. And I was really hesitant to review this place, because this has always been my lunch standby, whenever I was hungry at home and didn't want to cook.

However, as the price of gas went up, and expected the price food went up, the service went down. It used to be that during midday, you would find tons of Chinese construction workers eating here during their lunch break. But that's all kinda changed. There are less people eating here, and I've seen a rapid decline in business in the last year or so. 

The tables are sometimes really sticky, and the decor looks like it's seen better days. The waiters are kinda gruff, and rough around the edges, but they do try their best in terms of getting your order hot and fresh from the kitchen to your table. Ordering take-out is decent, I've never had to wait longer than 15 minutes for my order to come out. Sometimes it's out in 10 minutes.

Although this is a seafood restaurant, BEEF is their winning dish. Anything beef will practically do. Their beef chow fun is oily, but their portions are big, delicious, and awesome. The honey walnut prawns are incredible, and the clay pots are awesome as well. 

If you don't mind the hole-in-the-wall restaurant attitude, you'll find good food. And remember that if you don't like sitting in the restaurant, there's always their excellent take-out service. I'd highly recommend it.
author: Clinton L.

description:
This little canto place has got a lil' sumthin sumthin for everyone. I don't mean that both Jedi and Sith can eat in harmony here, but at least meat eaters and their sworn enemies vegetarians can eat at the same table. This is another hole in wall crap hole, with no decore to speak of, and some dirty ass table cloths. When the wife and i sat down, we stared at our dirty white table cloth and wondered if they had any money to spring for some fresh linens. Loud mouthed mother hens yelling cantonese at each other while bits of food fall off their mouths; waiters that look like they spent more time on their hair, than say, oh, skin care or brushing their teeth...yes, this place is a superstar among Chinese dives. 

But the food variety is very nice, and truth be told, their vegetarian stuff is not too bad. We ate with my Taoist mom, who has sworn off meat (sheesh -  her loss) and she had the "pepa" tofu, ong choy, and the fake seafood clay pot. they use some kind of soy meat substitute, and fashion it to look like the protein it is replacing. for example, in the clay pot there was piece of fake meat colored white and orange and shaped like a shrimp. Pretty tasty, actually, but it didn't taste like shrimp though. I also ordered the beef short rib and clams with "bad bean" sauce. the beef was tender, but the clams had some sand in them, but what do you expect from a dive? good food, great for bringing out the family, but definitely not good for a date. Nothing says "not gettin laid" like eating on a dirty table and food off bowls and plates bought at the 99 cent store in Chinatown.
author: Jerry C.

description:
I like the idea of a Chinese diner...we walked by at 2 PM and the place was almost full.  A lot of the large tables were occupied by Chinese families.  They have a Chinese language menu and tanks filled with fish, crabs and lobster, too.  Good signs in my book.

The popular dishes appear to be steamed (?) chicken and some very fatty type of pork (twice cooked?).  Those didn't appeal to me so we ordered a seafood claypot, lemon chicken, chicken in spicy chili sauce, shrimp with tender greens, and Mongolian beef.

The food wasn't bad but I wouldn't say it was good either.  The seafood claypot was the best of the dishes but some of the seafood tasted a little off.  The lemon chicken was deep fried and just looked icky (I didn't try it).  The chili sauce that came with the chicken was sweet, which I didn't like.  The Mongolian beef with crispy noodles was fine. 

The meat wasn't too tough but the sauces were heavy and goopy.  I was hoping for a light Cantonese style meal (if you're in this area and want that, too I suggest Eight Immortals).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Food: Ming's Diner is not bad.Tried the cashew chicken (which was tasty and had lots of chicken!) and the beef with snow peas (had a similar taste to the cashew chicken, but not bad).

Price: Prices here are cheap, mostly under $10 a dish.

Service: Was okay but not super friendly.

Atmosphere: The restaurant is a little dirty... (our table cloth was stained) while others were clean and white. Otherwise, definitely a Chinse family restaurant

Location: Located on Taraval near Kragen. Street parking and meters are available.
author: Miss H K.

description: Great place for a casual family dinner.  The family who owns this place is really nice.
author: Chrissy M.

description:
Came here recently with my family to have a very late Chinese New Year's Dinner.  We've come here before because my grandma and aunt are vegetarians and they have a vegetarian menu.  

I like this restaurant because it's a fairly priced place that serves up a lot of food.  We basically ordered their cheapest set dinner menu and ended up having to take home 5 boxes of food because we couldn't finish it all.  There were at least 2 whole dishes that we didn't even touch.  

My first comment is not to recommend whatever appetizer platter we started off with.  It was a jellyfish and chinese pancake dish.  The jellyfish was warm and way too oily.  It wasn't at all what I expected and I didn't eat any more of it.  

Everything else were pretty solid.  We had a deep-fried flounder, hong kong style pork, fried rice, crab, chicken, and more.  I don't remember all of the dishes exactly but it was all pretty good.  I particularly enjoyed the deep-fried flounder because it was juicy on the inside and crispy on the outside.  It was possible to eat most of the bones because of the way it was cooked.  At many restaurants I've been to, the bones aren't fried enough to warrant consumption.  

The restaurant is mainly a local haunt with two floors and plenty of free parking nearby.  I recommend this place for its price, location, and quality of the food.
author: Scott L.

description: Eh, the chinese food is so-so/not that great. It caters to vegetarian tastes, but even so, the flavors are not that good.  The vegetable dishes were so-so and the ox-tail was alright, but the sweet and sour pork was soggy and the pork-chop with onions were not that flavorful.  I have had much better Chinese food (especially in Southern California) and I can say this place is below average/sub-par.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
came here for a big family dinner (4 large tables).  

They have a 'private' room upstairs with 5 large tables max. if you are ever interested in using the place for a large group get together.

we ordered the $208/table of ten's pre-set menu.  which contains: walnut prawns, shark fin soup, lobster, fish, scallops over beans, appetizer plate, chicken, house friend rice etc...  (with the option of subbing certain dishes out with others)

portions were really big, and the food was pretty good.  

not really a diner, more of a restaurant.  not totally upscale, but certainly not hole in the wall.  typical chinese restaurant in the city.
author: Tina L.

description: My fiancé and I decided to pick up mother's day dinner for the future in laws. We ordered lemon chicken, beef and broccoli, mu shu chicken, salt and pepper pork chops, pot stickers, and combination pan fried noodles. Everything was delicious. Prices aren't bad either. $50 for everything. I was kind of upset because I phoned in the order and was told it will be ready for pick up in 25 minutes. When I arrived 30 minutes later...the food was not ready and had to wait another 15 minutes. They were really busy with the mother's day crowd. This was totally understandable but they had my cell number and could have told me that they were really busy and their kitchen is backed up and my order will not be ready. They did apologize for the wait. Whatever...I'm over it. I'll still be back for my Fook-chow fried rice for lunch when I decide to splurge on calories.
author: Jo S.

description:
Man, this review is going to be long cause my family has been coming to this restaurant for about 20 years.  About 15 years ago, they changed ownership.  As a child, I remember the waiters as being very friendly.  In the past few years, I've come to realize that they're actually pretty grumpy and rude, except for one who always says hi and stops to talk with us to talk about anything.  
Although Ming's specializes in vegetarian dishes, we never order anything vegetarian. My friends enjoy the chicken with chili sauce, which is slices of chicken sauteed with onions tossed in a chili sauce.  It's sweet, salty, and spicy all at the same time.  My family orders the same thing almost every week, rotating certain dishes. Just to name a few: 

onion pancake- sometimes they run out.  They are perfectly fried, crispy, and fluffy.  One time they gave us onion pancakes... instead of green onion, they put cilantro.  Took one bite and said WTF?! (I HATE cilantro)
lemon fish- i think it's fried chicken with lemon sauce on the menu, but we get fish instead.  It has a light batter and is always fried to perfection.  The fish is still moist and delicate inside and instead of having the sauce poured directly onto the fried goods, we have the sauce put on the side so that the fish stays crispy.
Crispy noodles- we order chicken with veggies, 3 meat, or tomato beef.  There's always a good amount of crispy noodles around the edge then the soft noodles which have been drenched in the sauce that's been put on top of the noodles.  The crispy part is my favorite, whereas the saucy parts are my cousins' favorites. Perrrrrrfect. 
Chow Fun- beef, or black bean beef.  Usually, I don't eat beef at many Chinese restaurants cause it tastes just like the cornstarch they've dunked the beef into to tenderize it, but Ming's beef tastes like actual beef.  The black bean chow fun is good.  They put just the right amount of sauce over the noodles where the black bean isn't overpowering the dish.
Greens- we order whatever vegetables we feel like eating that day.  They're always cooked perfectly where they're still crisp and juicy.
Soup- for lunch, they're basic soup is usually a soup that's been made from beef bone and random herbs.  Sometimes they serve a soup that's been boiled with carrots, which is slightly sweet.  If you like very mellow tasting soups, it's ok.  Sometimes, the soups are horrible... heavily diluted with water or something. The soups that come with the banquet style meals are good tho.

Based on other people's reviews, I guess it's a hit or miss.  Some of the things people have eaten, I didn't even know existed on the menu haha
I'd give Ming's 4 stars if only the waiters cracked a smile once in a while and didn't toss the dishes onto the table right before walking away.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Came back here on a tuesday around 6 and there was only 1 other table occupied. As a result, the service was quite good and the food arrived our table quite quickly. By the time we left the restaurant was almost at full capacity. Same average quality food with big portions. Since its close by and this time the serivice wasnt that bad, Ming;s has regained its status as the chinese restaurant of choice by default.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I grew up eating at Ming's. They recently remodeled the inside this summer, and even though the outside still looks.. well.. meh.. the inside is pretty nice and clean. I eat there at least once a week (take out or eat in). They have great food at cheap prices! My favorite dishes are:
walnut prawns
braised oxtail stew
most of the clay pots
fried flounder
seafood pan fried noodles
author: M B.

description:
As a chinese foodie, I was deeply ashamed at what is deemed chinese food here. I couldn't complain since this was the restaurant my father picked for his birthday dinner, but if I was the one being honored I would have seriously and profanely went off on what I was served last night.

First off, waiting isn't the problem...I chalked that up to no reservations and Saturday nights are always crowded...and it wasn't service, since we all know what it's like here anyways. BUT this review was just for the food...or the nasty seconds we tried to swallow..

You know the night's going to be bad when the complimentary soup in the beginning tasted like tepid bovine dish water...seriously...not even the 2 tablespoons of soy sauce could make this taste good. Not even my parents finished their first servings of that dreck. Then Dad got the squid with sour veggies plate, but it was so salty, that when I cried, the salt in my tears wasn't as bad as what was on that dish...and super oily. 
Second dish was some boiled shelled shrimp with carrots. I looked at this sad dish and said, okay, it's gonna be okay. First bite, blech...it was flavorless...absolutely no flavoring what so ever. What happened? Did I turn into an 85 year old with no taste buds??!! And the last dish was Beef Chow Fun...as ubiquitous as sweet and sour pork, you'd think a chinese restaurant wouldn't have found a way to F up this dish, but they did...oh yes, they did.
First off, the nasty oily aftertaste told us that they deep fried it with whatever leftover oil they had previously deep fried to death. Second, there was no FLAVOR!!! Again, no flavor...all I tasted was oil...even the beef was so oily, there was no words...gawd it's so bad, even my frugal parents told me not to box it up for home and it was barely touched! T__T.  Don't even get me started on their free "sweet" dessert soup...sweet my ass, it was swill, I tell you...flavorless swill!

I looked at everyone else at this place and thought, "My gawd, people! Do you know what crap they just served me? How can you still be eating at this faux chinese restaurant?" A pox on this place for all foodies and chinese people!!!
author: Pauline L.

description: Holy inexpensive Batman.  An incredible place for a cheap lunch.  Tasty too.  I ate there about 20 times because they have good size servings and the prces are low.
author: Cynthia B.

description: just went to Mings Diner on a monday for lunch just to try the Beef Won Ton Soup which is pretty good!!! So far, I have been to several Chinese Restaurants in the Taraval Street Area and have tried their Won Ton Noodle Soup... Which I like most when it comes to having lunch at these Chinese Restaurants...
author: William B.

description:
Looking for good chinese food can be tough if you don't want to be MSGed out or ordering the same dishes every time.  
Ming's offers a variety of cantonese dishes and even creative vegetarian ones as well.  This is the main reason we keep going back.
Vege. dishes include: herb chicken soup, stuffed tofu, eggplant eel, ham fried rice, and stir fried vege. squid.  Their beef ox tail stew is also good.
You can ask for specials and even have larger parties arranged for the upstairs.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Dinner is a hit or miss for us but lunch has always been great. Very affordable, free soup, mostly friendly service.

Must try: Onion porkchop rice, fujian fried rice, garlic fish w/ tender green, seafood over crispy fried noodle...all around $5+
author: s l.

description:
Old school Chinese restaurant. When my dad and I want an easy quiet place to eat at...this is it.

Simple dishes and quick service.

Mushroom chicken and string beans!!!
author: Eugene L.

description:
Food here is bland

a lil' expensive

Horrible customer service

The restaurant is always full/busy. Why? Don't ask me.

They will serve the big groups first even though you were there before them. Hey they're gonna make more money off the group than off one person right?

Every waiter was like "I'll be right with you." I was waiting for like 45 minutes to pick up my food. Then the woman took another 15 minutes to charge me. Cuz she was helping out all the big groups of families who just walked in.

I will never eat here again.
Had dinner on 6-6-09, ate pork chops,green onion pancake,cooked oysters,boiled chicken,calamari,squab,etc.  Food was good, as long as you don't order the fake veggie meats.
author: Jer W.

description:
Went here with a party of 20 - so two tables.  Had the $98 set menu that is good for 8 - 10 people (according to the menu).  Food was tasty - Crab, Chicken, Duck, Beef, Spinach, Flounder,  Sweet peas, Shrimp Tofu soup.  Unlike other Chinese restaurants, rice is usually included with the meal.  I believe this place charges $0.80 per person.

If you can overlook a few dirty cups and you want tasty, yet decently priced, Chinese food, check this place out.

It's not really a "Diner"...it's more of a restaurant.
author: Lise T.

description:
My mom and her friends went to Ming's for lunch and decided to bring the rest of the family to try it for dinner that same day. She says it was cheap and the food was good. Ok, I was convinced, so the entire family went. Parking is ok. You can drive down one of the residential streets to find parking. 

When we walked in, one of the waiters recognized my mom so we were seated right away. My mom ordered beef on a sizzling rice platter, fried tofu with broccoli, some type of pork dish and some type of vegetable dish. I must say...food was pretty good. You definitely get what you pay for. 

This restaurant is not the best on atmosphere but for the price you pay, you definitely don't go there for that. You go there for the food! I will definitely be back for more.
author: Karen R.

description:
They get an extra star for having a vegetarian menu and cooking the vegetarian food in separate pots and pans from the ones that use meat. Supposedly, at least.

You have to ask for the vegetarian menu and it is only in Chinese. I guess they think only Chinese people are vegetarians. Actually, only Chinese people that can READ Chinese. There are a lot of Chinese (ABC) that can't read Chinese. I only know a few words like "tofu". Practically everything had tofu, though. Luckily, my friend was from Taiwan and could read the menu.

The food is okay. I wasn't THAT impressed. We asked for something spicy and they gave us something that had chili peppers in it but it was not hot at all. I guess if you eat the chili peppers it would be.

The thing that really annoyed me was how they ignore you. Someone came by and saw that we were done. I thought he was going to go get the check but he never did. And then we had to ask someone for the check. And then they didn't seem to want our money since they never came around to get it! I think we probably could have just left without paying and they wouldn't have noticed. It's not like they were super busy or anything.

The place is also a little grimy and gross.

If you have no other options, this place is ok. Just don't go if you are on a schedule or something because it'll take longer than it has to.
author: Lola S.

description:
This "diner" which is really a restaurant, has been in the neighborhood for years and they have their share of regulars, including the group of painters/contractors who came in for lunch, or the elderly lady w/her daughter who was happily greeted by the waiter who obviously knew her. 

I used to order their sticky rice chicken which takes 20 mins to make. A sticky concoction of rice with Chinese sausage (lop cheung), stuffed into deboned chicken meat, then quickly fried so there's a nice crispy, crunchy exterior.  But today, that dish was rather bland and the exterior was more chewy than crispy.  The Mongolian beef over rice ($4.95) wasn't spicy enough and lacked flavor as well.  The chicken pan-fried noodles ($4.95)were OK as was the beef chow fun ($4.95). Maybe they have a new chef or it's the weekend crew but the food today lacked flavor even 'tho the portions were generous.  The lunch menu is served daily from 11AM-3PM, all dishes about $4.95 except for the oxtail/red wine sauce over rice for $5.75.  Hubby said, "This place must be good, look at all the contractors eating here."  After I pointed out inexpensive does not equate quality dining, he agreed, "Cheap eats, 'tho".
author: Ry T.

description:
This place is always packed!  I've eaten here about 4 times, and sometimes the wait is too long so I go to Han Goeng's instead.  The food costs a few dollars more per dish than Han Goeng's, but it is also usually a little bit better here.  However, because it's always busy, I feel like the service caters to older patrons more and you are neglected if your group is full of people in their 20s.  My roommate does not like this place because he feels that they don't treat us as well because they think that we're kids and they don't want to wait on us. Try to get a table on the lower level because service is very very scarce if you're sitting on the second floor.  

I got the $128 banquet meal here and we made some substitutions to it, so it ended up costing a bit more.  I added garlic sauteed pea sprouts and beef oxtail clay pot here and both dishes were very good.  I especially liked the oxtail because it was very tender and the meat would fall off the bone, as if it's been cooking for hours.  The peking duck was also very good and I liked the duck skin and dough buns.  There wasn't much meat on the duck though, but I think that might be how peking duck is served.  The sauteed scallops and shrimp dish was also good. The portion was very large and tasted very fresh.  They also gave us a huge deep fried flounder.  I thought that most of the fish was good, especially the crispy skin, which was fried with garlic.  However, parts of the fish were kinda fishy.  I took the fish home because there was so much left over, and that was when I found that one particular area of the fish tasted like ammonia.  So I 'm pretty sure that part of the fish had gone bad.  The only other dish that was dissappointing was the dual lobsters.  The lobsters that we got were tiny!  The claws and tail portions were so small that I think they must have given us baby lobsters or giant crawfish, lol!  If I had to guess, I would say that they were between 3/4 of a pound to 1 pound each.  What annoyed me was that we had actually gotten the banquet meal with 2 crabs and they were trying to get me to exchange the crabs for lobsters. I spoke with my group and we felt that crabs would be fine, and turned down the offer, but then they came back and said that they had run out of crabs.  I felt that the whole incident was kind of shady, and that they might have taken advantage of us, especially after we ended up with tiny lobsters.

Oh, and they charge $1 per person for rice.  That's pretty annoying because rice should be included with banquet dinners.  Can you believe a restaurant would charge $10 for rice if there are 10 people?  You can buy a 20 pound bag of good short grain rice for that!
author: Tyler C.

description: I'm barely giving it 2 stars.  After my parents and brother inlaw's parents told me what happened before I got there.  After just getting there, they told me that the person in the front said the place was booked, so either you wait or you can get out, rudely!!!  What saved them to get an 2 star was the waiter came over and said they had tables upstairs, he was friendly and funny.  Food was average, not exciting.  Can't get over the rudeness, that's uncalled for.
author: Peter L.

description:
What the heck.....Came here last night with a very large group of about 30, for a birthday. They have a 2nd floor for larger groups, which is where we were all seated. (side note if you sit up there along the back wall be careful since all the chairs are stacked against the wall right next to those tables)

Let's start off with the fact that I have been here before but it's been such a long time, from what I remember was that we would always have to ask for water and the food was fairly good.

Now for last nights experience where to even begin.  Don't get me wrong I do love Chinese food also to note vegan, vegetarian chinese food as well. Waiting for the dinner to start a server who I might note wasn't in the best mood brought out cut up lettuce for a dish; it sat there for nearly an hour because the actual dish it was served with didn't come out for an hour. i didn't know how much food was ordered but we had about 10 different dishes (or something like that) sent to each table we had which was 3, so 30 dishes for all of us total? A lot of food. Their sweet pork ribs were and are still delicious one thing consistant from my older visits. Most of the food was alright, not gross or anything a fairly OK, I'd have to say. BUT there was one dish that was sent back, it was deep fried fish with garlic and soy sauce, the outside was cooked for sure but when we cut it up, usually fried fish cuts well when fully cooked but the fish was still mushy on the inside and pink, so whoops that went back.

All the servers we had that night were cantonese, I don't speak but my boyfriend and all of his family do. But let's get to the service which is why there were rated so low. I noticed the server would stomp his feet up the stairs and non stop talk and even some costumers would talk back. I didn't ask but those that understood would tell me what was going on. One thing was that someone asked for more water and he told the costumer to get it himself, or even told someone to shut up at their table. My response, what who says that?! I understand why our food took so long to come out besides the fact that it was super busy it was the fact that there were so many of us, so much ordered but get this....

Everyone started to get full from what was already served (no one really knew at least at our table, what and how much stuff was ordered) but we were given to go boxes from the servers to pack up the stuff we had left over... BUT THEY KEPT SERVING US FOOD THAT WE SUPPOSEDLY ORDERED!? I know some of you are thinking yeah but you ordered that stuff  we were there nearly 3 hours you give us boxes WHILE you still have food coming out to us? SHEESH... 

From the service to sending back food I felt like I was in chef Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares. I bet the kitchen was insane with all the orders but never have I seen or heard any servers talk to any costumers in that manner in all the places I've lived or visited. 

I've never encountered any of this in the past at this place but geez....

parking sucks...
author: Steph S.

description: What drew me and my family in to this restaurant is that they serve VEGETARIAN DISHES!! Do you know how HARD it is to find a chinese restaurant with one black sheep vegetarian in the family? Their vegetarian dishes were definitely up to par with my standards and it felt like I was finally able to eat Chinese food again.
author: Lily Z.

description: Maybe I came in on a bad day, but honestly... tofu should not have the consistency of milk.
author: Israel C.

description: Good food (and portion size for the price for us "bigger eaters"!). Friendly service and atmosphere. Would definitely go back again :-).
author: Kevin P.

description: Ming's has become a favorite of my family's since it caters to both vegetarians and carnivores.  Their vegetarian dishes are super awesome and their meat and seafood dishes are yummy too.  I absolutely love their Ginger & Scallion Oyster dish.  They fry the oysters first so they are nice and crispy with lots of scallions...yum-O!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
When I'm going for authentic Chinese, I am not looking for atmosphere, or service, that is for sure.  If you go into this place knowing that then you will enjoy your meal as the food is great!  

I have been here at least 15 times and had good food each time.  My father likes it too,so Leon if you were waiting for a "Mr. Quan approved" restaurant this is it.  

Today we had the black bean sauce and beef chow fun, honey walnut shrimps and the BBQ pork with vegetables.  The BBQ pork, I wasn't a big fan of today, as the vegetables took away from the flavor for me, but everything else was good.  And because they recognize my father, the service though not 5 star, is better than it normally would be if it had just been me.

Update 3/19/2007
Ok, so we went there for dinner also, the same day.  What can I say?  We had a family dinner, and my mother and grandmother are super strict Buddhist vegetarians, and Ming's has a full vegetarian menu of food that they cook on a separate range so that the pots and pans and smells don't mix with that of the meat dishes which is ideal with what their religion would like, though they know not every restaurant can promise that.  Their vegetarian menu also doesn't use garlic or onions which goes with the Buddhist guidelines for eating.

So for us normal meat eating family members at the dinner, we had 2 kinds of crab which were amazing, messy but great in flavor and taste.  (If you had to pick one, my BF liked the salt and pepper crab the best for the flavor).  That came alongside with a complimentary plate of onion pancakes which were tasty and very flavorful.  Following the pancakes came a squab which I didn't get to try but  from what I could see everyone was enjoying.  ( I was too busy eating the onion pancakes and when I was done there was no more squab!)  We also had chicken and squid dish which was good, but for me, the highlight was the soy sauce fish!  I don't know what kind of fish it is but it is made with a soy sauce mix on it that is amazing.......the fish melts in your mouth and over some white rice, I could have just had that all night and been perfectly happy.  It's always my favorite dish at Mings...........seriously.  I love it.  Every time we have a family dinner there, my father, aunt or whoever is ordering it makes sure I get that otherwise I will admit, I whine like a 7 year old the rest of the night.  I left Mings content, full and still dreaming of the soy sauce fish.  

If you go there, all the men are nice, if you make the effort.  We have been going for years and they are all nice, Kevin is the only waiter though whose name I actually know because my dad is always calling his name out to bring more napkins and to change the plates for us.  

Oh, and Leon, per Mr. Quan, you must must get the lobster chow mien if you are there. We tried to get it today, but they were out of lobster.  How dare they!!

Updated 3/2/2007
Ooh went again tonight. Add to the list of things that were good: the mu shu pork- mixture of pork and vegetables and some sauce that you wrap up like a burrito in a flat Chinese type tortilla..........also the soy sauce chicken was good!  And my uncle swore by the long shelled clams- he liked them so much he ordered a second plate to go........this one is not on the menu, just ask the waiter about any specials not on the menu!

Update 7/14/2007
Oh I forgot to mention there is no alcohol here, BUT you can bring your own.  We always cart in a cooler of beer and wine and stuff.  How great is that?
author: Denise B.

description: Haven't been here since high school but their food used to be super duper dirty cheap. $2.88 for pork loaf and salted fish bits? Awesome. I had low standards for food back then because I really didn't care. Looking back, this place is pretty dirty. The food they give you is pretty cheap quality and made like it's whatever. Definitely don't bring your date here. It's not date friendly because it can get super loud and the food just doesn't look pretty when it comes to the table. They pretty much just slap on anything on a plate. You could do better. Loosen up the purse strings. Haha.
author: Jenny T.

description: Great Chinese food. No fuss, big portions, low prices. I like their Mongolian beef and House special pan friend noodles. I usually go their with my family and we order the set menu dishes wish are all great.
author: Emily C.

description:
In the foggy cold outer sunset, where can go to fill your tommy?
Here is a place that looks more nastier outside then inside.  It's always about the food but you don't want the risk of eatting insects and encounter with other creatures of nastiness.  There was a dam dirty nasty chinese place at Taraval and 19th.  The food is dam good but the flies and roach wants to fight for your food as you eat is gross.
So Ming is a better choice for me. 
 We order 3 dishes and the portion is very generous.  We did not make a dent in meal.  There was also complimentary soup and dessert.  Soup was great don't know what's in it but the usual chinese vegi and bone light soup.  Needless to say we bag it all back home and they taste even better the next day.
I think it is what you pay for too.  I have been to other chinese place with lower price, the portion is a lot smaller.  There were lots of people waiting.  Lots of local family eat there.  They have big tables mostly for groups and a upstair for parties.  The service is the worse part.  I think they cater mostly to big groups as other reviews have said.  I think they jump to help the bigger group first because they will get a bigger tip since they order more food.  I saw other tables order all vegetarian meals.  They sure have a lot of choices for them.  In short this is not a bad place if you don't mind waiting a bid if you are not in a big group.
author: Mar H.

description:
mings isn't a fancy schmancy chinese place, but the food is really excellent.  however, ive only eaten the vegetarian dishes.  :)  they have a special menu and its all in chinese, so make sure to bring friends that can read, at least.  and don't forget to ask for the special veggie menu!  

items i really enjoy are...

~ sweet and sour soy pork
~ pipa tofu
~ lettuce cups
~ veggie bbq spare ribs
~ soup with some kind of sea grass?
author: Wendy S.

description: Ordinary Chinese Family type place w/ extraordinary customer service. OH and they're cheap. My family usually come here and order the set menu and we usually add oysters and such. There's always plenty of spaces, since they do have additional seating upstairs. We almost never have to wait. Their food comes fast. For 13 people, it was $150 ish. Which is not bad since we had oysters, crab, fish, duck, scallops. Tons of seafood. When you leave they always thank you for choosing them. We usually come here when we don't want a dent in our wallets.
author: MT D.

description: I go here atleast once a week here for lunch. I don't go here for the service, nor do i go here for the atmosphere. I go here for the food. The food is great here. The salt and pepper spare ribs are great, the rock cod with corn! EXCELLENT! Peking Spare ribs are ALSO GREAT!!! Everything is pretty cheap.
author: Brian P.

description: UPDATE: So I ordered a total of $12.60 worth of food on 08/07/08. I paid with my debit card. HOWEVER, the lady who charged me, placed a hold of almost $200 on my account!!! FOr the $12 worth of food. If you go here...do NOT pay with your debit card. Pay cash. I'm not Chinese so I don't know if it was because I wasn't that she maybe thought my card didn't have enough money on it to go through. This is WACK! Not sure what complaining to her will do since it's independently owned and rude anyway when you're a sit down-before you pay customer. Just FYI.
author: Richard F.

description: This place is good and one of the better chinese restaurants in Parkside. I've gotten lunch take-out here and also had dinners here a lot. Hubby and his daughter are not chinese but we are always treated nicely.  Eggplant dishes are really tasty! Their mu-shu pork is not one of my favorites, but everything else is always fresh and good. I think they remodeled recently - looks cleaner and brighter (chinese restaurants love their flourescent lights). Definitely one of my go-tos in the neighborhood when I want chinese food!
author: Amy H.

description: If you go for dinner, they have the BEST free soup ever ever. It's just a simple broth with some meat and vegetables for flavor, but it's so rich and delicious. Almost as good as grandma's!
author: Jacquee P.

description: I've been to this restuarant for quite a number of years in the past till today. Back then, the food was pretty good! As time went by, this place is like a roller coaster, keeps on going up and down again and again! One day your experience is pretty decent! Other days are just a complete disaster! Service is way below par! Some waiters are very moody! I noticed if you order the more expensive items, they tend to treat you better! But again, if I was really planning on to spend more money, there is no way on earth would I go there to eat! It has plenty of competitors around the area that has way better food, service and value! The place is so outdated! I know they renovated the place a short while ago, but it hardly or barely changed the environment. The tables and chairs are so outdated and worn out. The chairs can break very easily if you happen to sit on a bad one! Food quality is terrible! Alot of grease and the taste is very bland! I ordered a plate of sizziling beef with onions the other day! It took over half an hour for it to reach my table. I don't mind waiting if the plate comes out really good! But when I saw it, I was so disappointed with what they gave me after all that time waiting! 3/4 of the plate was all onions, 1/4 of it was the beef! The beef for some reason were chopped up into many small pieces. It was like for a three year old eating it. The beef was very tough to eat! Not much seasoning and very greasy! They really ought to change their service and food quality besides jacking up their prices! Their value and quality is really sinking everytime I go back there!
author: Vince F.

description: The food is great, and authentic! It's probably my favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. I would of given it more stars, but this is not a first date restaurant. Bring a jacket in case you set near the door. If you want quality, and quantity look no further. The $98 set menu dinner is a great bargain. My personal favorites is the salt and pepper pork chops w/fried tofu, and stewed ox tails. The lemon chicken is good, but that "tourist" Chinese food. :)
author: Gilbert D.

description: Good food, great and kind service, very good prices. Sanitary.
author: Keit K.

description:
Ming's is our family staple.  My big crazy family has been coming here for as long as I can remember.  My uncles love the place because of the BYOB. The rest of us love this place because the food is consistently good and the prices are entirely reasonable.

Dishes are great, but upon reading other reviews - I realized that we've never ordered off the menu.  We sit down, the waiters come by with their pads and in the midst of every one of us yelling out options, we come to an agreement and dishes are brought out.

The chef is very good with the most random ingredients - everything that we've had has always been done very well.  It's more home-style cooking than anything else.  Try the steamed crab with garlic and rice wine - very tasty! Oxtail stew, roasted quail, Salt & Pepper tofu and pork riblets, Poached chicken....just a few options to try.
author: Caryn L.

description: Best deal on chinese food currently in the sunset. The decor isn't all that but the quality to price ratio of the food is great. Gotta try the chicken pan fried noodles
author: B. C.

description: This place is amazing for vegetarians! I am so happy to have delicious Chinese food around the corner. The pine nut fried rice is the best! Really affordable too! Super cheap!
author: Myfood Y.

description: My husband's aunt is vegertarian, so she suggested coming to this place last time, since they serve both veg and meat dishes.  My parents, my sister and I came here today and the Chinese veggie dishes were all very good.  We ordered veggie mushu pork, veggie sweet and sour pork, veggie pork kidneys stirr-fried in Chinese BBQ sauce, and tofu.  They were all seasoned fairly well.  My mom couldn't even believe it's veggie!  We will come back for sure if we crave Chinese vegetarian again.
author: Vicky F.

description:
We used to be regulars here. Loved the food, authentic Chinese food. We are Caucasian (so not Asian) and there definitely is a difference in the waiters attitude if you are asian, but we ignored this, as the food made us return here often.. 

Finally, we stopped going here. Why? 

Twice found some type of small metal object in our dish. (on 2 separate occasions-  I bit into this and was lucky enough to catch it), once hey it can happen, but when it happened a second time, its time to move on. 

Could have broken a tooth or swallowed it, and that is a bit too much excitement to anticipate while eating dinner. When I showed them, the looked at it, and asked if I wanted them to redo the dish? They actually looked at me, with a strange look, like what does he want us to do?

Fortunately, we have expanded our horizons and thanks to Yelp, found a number of interesting, Chinese restaurants that have great food here.
author: G L.

description: I will never go here again. I don't know if it's because I'm white (half white) or what but the service I've gotten here is horrific. The waiter almost threw the forks on the table from a foot above the table. The place smells like their aquariums are not very clean. The food can be pretty good, but there's so much pulling this place down I would say do not go.
author: Gregory M.

description:
This place here is typical of many small Chinese restaurants but they take it to the next level, EXTREMELY POOR SERVICE WITH A ATTITUDE. The waiters here are impossible to communicate with and asking them for the simplest of things like napkins or an extra plate is accommodated with a dirty look like your bothering them. 

The food here is actually ok but poor service & waiters with attitude problems are not. The manager/owner, this older woman with glasses just sits there and does nothing but looks around the restaurant like someone is going to run off without paying. When we asked her for the check and a box, she just ignored us. HELLO? Do I need to yell at you to get your attention? 

I will also be extremely cautious of ordering something that isn't on a menu or have a price posted. They charged us a ridiculous $13 for pea sprouts and garlic ... what a RIP OFF. My wife also had a sweet tooth that night and asked about the desert after the main meal. The waiter had the nerve to say they are out when another waiter just bought out 10 servings to the table next to us. 

Anyway, we won't be coming back and you should think twice about patronage a restaurant who is only interested in your $$$$ and not your dinning pleasure.
author: John S.

description:
This place is ok.  We came here after ready fairly good reviews here, but we were somewhat disappointed.

We ordered a set dinner for 4 to 6 people.  We were only 2 adults and 2 very small children.  The food was ok, but it's a little oily.  The service was above average.  They are friendly and changes your plate as they get full with bones/shells (which doesn't happen all the time in a Chinese restaurant).  Their bathroom is clean.  

What really angered me is the portion we were served.  People keep saying the serving size is generous.  We didn't see that at ALL.  They are pulling something because we ordered more than enough food with only 2 adults and 2 small children.  The table next to us with 5 adults ordered the same set dinner, yet their portion is MUCH larger.  It actually angered me so much I was going to say something.  The waiter brings the food out at the same time for both tables (I guess we ordered around the same time), and he drops the food at our table first because we are closer to the back.  He would hold 2 plates of the identical food, but one is ALWAYS larger than the other.  He would always happen to drop off the small plate at our table.  It was VERYYYYY annoying.  Our crab was small with only one claw.  Their crab was much bigger.  That was just messed up.  That kind of ruined my appetite.  We finished almost all our food and it was supposed to be for 4 to 6 people.  Keep in mind that our children ate very little.  We always have lots of left overs at other Chinese places when we order a large set dinner.

We felt we did not get what we paid for.  We will not be coming back.
author: Jon J.

description: Good food, great prices, and attentive staff! Minus 1 star for the dirty dishes that were on the table when my family and I went there. Also, it's probably best to skip the white rice and order fried rice since the white rice is rather cold and looks like it was been sitting overnight. Overall a great place to dine with family and friends. I would highly recommend their seafood dishes (especially the salt and pepper roasted crab!) :P
author: Danny Y.

description: WOW! I've passed this place probably hundreds of times and haven't bothered to go in, from the outside it looks very inconspicuous.  Finally last night, my housemate and I didn't want to wait for our place down the street to open up, so we came here. service was QUICK as hell - we placed a 4-dish order and had all 4 dishes on our table in under 5 minutes. The Mongolian Beef was made right (with the crunchy noodles!), and the Chow Fun was pretty good too.  We had plenty of leftovers, and it was cheap! No complaints here.
author: Jeremy L.

description: I go here with my family when my mom doesn't want to cook. It's affordable and the portions are good. We love the seafood here. The staff is friendly and they can recommend thing that are fresh in the kitchen.
author: bob k.

description:
i had a pretty bad experience here. if ur expecting fast service you will not find it here, at least not for me. i have no clue if it was just the wrong time but getting the menu took awhile and receiving the check as well. i had the urge to walk out a couple of times...i didnt of course. 

i ordered the chicken salad to start. it tasted good initially but after a few bites i was done. i also ordered the duck and pickled veggies noodle soup, the broth was on the bland side. overall, i wouldnt suggest going here. it was below average for me.
author: Nikoh C.
